Bewildered as to why this was so harshly treated. Not quite a fantastic four stars but definitely improves on the embarrassing originals. Those begging for the light-hearted, tongue in cheek approach of most other Marvel movies will understandably be disappointed and perhaps rightfully claim it is disloyal to the comics. In my opinion, this serious sci-fi themed reboot works. It fleshes out the origin story and conveys a more humanistic interpretation of the superhero team. Human Torch is no longer an American jock stereotype but remains flawed with naivety while The Thing is developed from simply being the big, dumb comic relief. This 'Fantastic Four' re-imagining also shows that superhero films don't have to be overloaded with action in order to be entertaining. Albeit there is less 'fun' to be had since you do have to wait a while before their powers are used and in the end the conflict with Dr Doom does rely on contrived elements but I can't say I found any particular part dull. I recommend the rest of you ignore the masses, take a break from these standard Marvel/wannabe comedy films and give the new 'Fantastic Four' a chance.

I actually reasonably enjoyed the start of this movie,. As a light sci-fi, it was working well, until around the time they go to the other dimension and it starts to turn back into a superhero movie. Then it kinda lost my interest.
Still, I could see the intent behind much of the screenplay, sometimes it came out well, other times it fell flat. I think the main problem was the pacing. The second and third parts of the movie (after the 'accident') just feel rushed and underwhelming. And Doom was kinda butchered. I could see what they were going for, but again rushed, underdeveloped, and ended up feeling absurd.

Perhaps it's the fact that I had low expectation for this film. I didn't hate it, in fact, I was really into it for the first 50 minutes or so. I thought it was a really cool space travel adventure with some interesting ideas, and I felt Josh Trank's confidence and passion through his direction. I liked the cast (I'm a big fan of all 4 leads), and they seemed to be having fun during the first 50 minutes. I understand this was a troubled production and I can see why the majority of people hated it. It completely falls apart in the third act and nothing in the film makes sense (e.g. Why are they doing this inter-dimension travel thing in the first place? Why is earth dying?) I felt that a lot of things were cut out from the original cut, and the studio's interference ultimately killed the film. That said, this is not the worst superhero film ever made. It's not a good movie, but it certainly isn't as awful as everyone says it is. Fant4stic is stupid, clunky, and incomprehensible, but there is a lot of good stuff in it that I kind of had fun time with it. It's not that bad.

Okay, it's not Hamlet, we get it, but it's not like the reboot of the Fantastic Four (2015) as one reviewer related Warcraft to.  Last I looked Warcraft was a sporting a 27/83 rating vs. FF's 9/19.  Let me state that I'm a WoW fan, but  really didn't know the lore too well or the main characters.  I've seen it twice already and would like to go again.  The problem I see with Warcraft is that the lore has been fleshed out majorly and there is tons of it.  Parallel story lines snake through it on multiple continents and planets.  Lord of the Rings had a lot of characters, but they seemed to going in the same direction.  By the time the Peter Jackson's version screened it had already been attempted as a movie.  Even Leonard Nimoy had done a song about it.  Warcraft is exciting and well paced.  They don't spend time on ten minute fight scenes between two characters and spend it advancing the story instead.  And there is plenty of that to cover.  A lot of these reviewers don't get it.  They are going to say Steel Magnolias and Pretty Woman are better films, no, they are for different audiences.

After months of hearing how bad this movie sucked, I finally got to chance to sit down and give it a go. It know it will sound like a broken record at this point, but the first 30-40 minutes of this movie are actually pretty darn good. This movie had a fantastic cast (pun intended), and it's a shame when you see how well some of their early scenes played out. There were even a couple of lines that made me chuckle at the beginning. Oh, and while we're on the subject, I thought Toby Kebbell as Pre-Dr. Doom was great. I even had to IMDB him to figure out who the heck he was. I could imagine him as a GoT character for some reason, don't ask why.

The latter half of the movie feels very rushed, and this is where the problem lies. It could have been, at the least, on the level of those Andrew Garfield Spider-man movies had they just fleshed the character's out a little more. The last 30 minutes are so rushed, it reminded me of the pilot for another CW superhero TV series. I can't help but feel all the rumors about FOX meddling with the production are true, because you really have to stretch to make some of the scenes make sense. 

A couple more of my opinions on the movie. 

1. The scene with Doom breaking out of the facility was kick ass. 
2. Final fight was lame city. 
3. I hated The Thing's voice.
4. They needed to give Mara and Teller better lines. Great talent wasted here. 
5. The pre-fantastic versions of Ben and Victor made me hate the fantastic versions even more. These guys are fantastic actors and I've never even heard of them. 
6. Michael B. Jordan as Johnny Storm felt the most like his comic book counterpart for me. Wish he had more scenes.

This film was atrocious. I can't believe how much they dropped the ball on this one... Let me explain the positives/negatives.

Positives:
1. The scene with Reed and Ben as kids was handled okay.

2. Victor von Doom killing people in the hallway looked creepy and not that bad.

3. The cast is trying despite given a terrible script.

4. There is potential because of Josh Trank directing, who did direct Chronicle which is my favourite found footage film.

Negatives:
1. The performances; every character sounds like they are contractually obligated everytime they speak. Nobody feels like a person the acting is very mechanical and dry. Even though the cast is good and I can tell they are trying the things they are saying just don't work and the jokes don't hit!

2. The tone; this film takes itself way too seriously. The jokes (if there are any!) don't hit at all, this film is so uninspired, it makes the previous Fantastic Four movies look good, because at least you kind of laugh at how bad they are but this film takes itself too seriously. Serious tones only work for certain films like The Dark Knight, but it doesn't work here!

3. The villain; what happened!? Victor von Doom is a joke in this film, not only is he weak but he has no motivation. He is just a bad guy and he looks horrible! At least in the 2005 Fantastic Four they atleast got Dr. Doom's costume right, here they attempt to translate him on the big screen but they do it completely wrong! Dr. Doom is one of the most badass villains and they took a complete dump all over him!

4. The final battle is atrocious, this whole film is boring lacking any action. Now we finally get an action scene but it is terrible and forgettable. One punch and Dr. Doom is defeated. No epic showdown, nothing! Good job guys....

Overall:
This might actually be my least favourite comic book film. Don't watch this movie, don't even watch it on Netflix like I did. Poor Josh Trank, he was treated like an animal by 20th Century Fox. I'm just waiting until Fox gives Fantastic Four back to Marvel. All of those positives I listed aren't enough to be redeeming qualities. Absolutely disappointing excuse of a film.

Despite its glowing 9% on Rotten Tomatoes I decided to watch this. While I cannot say it is good, cause it is not, it was not the disaster I was led to believe. There were glimmers of promise in this. The story was fine actually, basically a 100 minute origin story, not confusing and which set up any sequels really well. Generally the special effects were good, and there were a few moments after they had gotten their powers where I found myself enjoying it. The first half was a lot better than the second half. The main problems were the horrible, stilted, dialogue, mainly during the second half of the movie, and two very bad casting choices.  Miles Teller was great in Whiplash, but really miscast in this. He simply doesn't have the weight or projected maturity to carry off the role of Reed Richards. Also, Michael B. Jordan just was not suited to his role as the Human Torch...his comedic timing was horrible. Too bad Chris Evans is now Captain America. His Human Torch in the previous Fantastic Four attempts was the best thing about those movies. Kate Mara was fine, and actually Jamie Bell was really good as Ben Grimm. Anyway, if they are going to attempt a sequel, they need to replace Miles Teller and Michael B. Jordan, and find a writer who knows how to write dialog for these types of superhero movies. Anyway, if you have an afternoon without anything else to do, this is worth watching, otherwise I wouldn't go out of my way.

I really hope someone can crack the code for a solid Fantastic Four film, but obviously not today. Rating: 11

When this movie was announced I was quite excited to see it because the director behind Chronicle had been given the job of bringing a new version of the Fantastic Four to the big screen.  Chronicle was a complete re-imagining of the superhero genre, Josh Trank and writer Max Landis created something cool, new and fresh to the genre and so I was very much hoping the rules learnt in Chronicle would be applied here.  Sadly this was not to be, whether this is down to the absence of Landis or studio meddling is debatable but the film was quite a mess.
The was a substantial set up before we see the Fantastic Four in action which I don't mind if it is done well but I felt the actors weren't quite right for the roles and the dialogue was very messy.  On a positive point I thought the transformation scenes would done quite well and rested more in the body horror genre than the superhero genre.  Well, this is true with the exception of Victor Doom who looked ridiculous, like a failed idea from Doctor Who :o(
The first half of the film was entertaining enough to keep me watching but disappointingly it was once they became the superheroes that I started to lose interest.  The film was leading up to a battle with Doom which took place for 10 mins at the end on another planet and was fairly uneventful, this made the 2nd half of the film even more disappointing and then we have the final line of the movie and the origin of the superhero teams name which was so cringey it made my skin hurt.
To be fair, the Fantastic Four is a difficult concept to bring to the big screen.  The Human Torch and Invisible Woman are fairly simple ideas but the Thing often comes across as looking too cartoon like and Mr Fantastic is just a live action version of Stretch Armstrong.  They need to forget trying to adapt the exact visual concepts from the comic book and reinvent The Thing and Fantastic for the big screen.  Time to hand the rights back to Marvel, hopefully they can fix this mess.

Jordan did a better job as Human Torch then i expected but this is Fantastic Four, collectivism is as important individual. Seeing the four characters in this film as Fantastic Four was just awkward. It's like "i'll pick you, i'll pick him, pick her and him. Okay you're the Fantastic Four" type of randomness.

Yet another version of the Fantastic Four, while the early 2000s version wasn't bad, it never really caught on. Let's not talk about the 1990s version. Reed is a high school science wiz who catches the eye of a researcher who brings them in to work for them. The actors are way too old to be roughly high school/college age so that's the first knock. The actor who plays Reed Richards is also miscast as he feels more like a sidekick at best than the eventually leader. Michael B. Jordan is probably the best actor here and is barely used at all. Kate Mara lives up to her moniker as the Invisible Woman since you often forget about her as she is just sitting at computers most of the time. The Thing also just feels like a waste.

It doesn't help that they whole crew isn't brought together until about 1/3 of the way through, then they spend the next 1/3 wondering why they have super powers, then the next 1/3 battling the bad guy who just gets introduced in the last 20 minutes and they finally become a team with 5 seconds to go. It's horribly paced. It'd needed to combine the first two acts into one and make the third act longer. 

There are elements of this movie that could have been good, it needed a better cast and the editing needed to be better. The villain was excellent, but he is only in the film for a few minutes. The dark tone works in spots, but I feel this franchise more than most is generally very cheery and family friendly and they went the dark and gritty which tonally didn't work like it should. A second installment might fix a lot of the issues, but I'm not sure I'd be interested in seeing it at this point barring another major reboot.

Fantastic Four was a fantastic failure.  The concept and the heroes should make for a great film but the way this re-boot was done, it took all the fun out of it.  Almost the entire movie was a buildup and a backstory to how the team met and eventually got the special powers.  Even thought that aspect took over an hour, you still did not feel connected to the characters and it was a long drawn out process.  Once things finally got going there were a couple fun action scenes that were over much to quickly.  It all felt rushed at the end and it was not a fulfilling ending at all. They completely missed the whole point with this film, it wasn't funny, it wasn't action packed, it was slow and boring and while they tried to set it all up for a multi film franchise, it should never continue after this screw up.

This is my first review of a movie on Rotten Tomatoes.  I watched this movie the next day after watching Captain America: Civil War.  This recently dropped on HBO so I decided to watch the only Marvel movie over the past 16 years I have not watched.  I knew about the harsh reviews of this movie but I wanted to give it a chance.  

I was thoroughly disappointed by this movie.  Put it this way, if Captain America: Civil War is your most favorite pie (mine is French Silk pie) this movie is just the pie crust.  No filling, no remnants of what was there.  Just the crust.  Perhaps there are people out there who love flavorless pie crust.  I don't.  I sat there watching and wishing there was more to this pie than just the crust.  I was waiting and waiting but.....nothing.  Right off the bat people were freaking out about Johnny Storm being black.  That was such a non-issue as Michael B. Jordan is a fine actor (go watch Creed if you haven't already).  Out of the four he did the best acting.  I really enjoyed the Fantastic Four movie in 2005.  It wasn't perfect by any means and the special effects were poor but that cast was far more likable.  I'm sure all of these young actors are good actors but their direction was terrible, especially Jamie Bell's performance of Ben Grimm.  Michael Chiklis was 100x better.  There was nothing redeeming about this movie.  This should have never happened.

Despite it's reputation, I do admire the film, and the director clearly had a distinct vision of the story he wanted to tell... even if perhaps it was better if he didn't tell it at all.

WHAT gave them power and WHERE is the other "Earth? I would go on? But why bother! Josh Trankuilizer obviously got his check cashed and is tanning away north of ZUMA beach. Personally I'm going camping up in Topanga Canyon. See ya,hate ta be ya!

It's highly likely that we'll never understand fully just what happened
behind the scenes of Fantastic Four to make it the film it is today.

It's a film that even the most pessimistic of comic book haters,
popcorn disliking, nerd despising, anti-movie fiends couldn't have
predicted the amount of hate thrown its way and the ill will that Josh
Trank's second feature film received upon release.

Box Office receipts were dire, critics tore shreds of a film they
labelled "boring" or "to dark" and many including audiences were
bemused at how this supposed comic book film floated by for near on an
hour of running time to then descend into a chaotic final act of
atrocious CGI and one of modern movie history's most poorly constructed
and underdeveloped villains.

The mystery surrounding Fantastic Four's failure flows from studio
interference, including the studio butchering a rushed re-edit of the
film before release, director Josh Trank's bizarre on set behaviours
and mismanagement of actors and all manner of script writers for hire
coming in and having a go at trying to make something of Trank's
clearly going for bleak re-telling of an already previously mismanaged
franchise (Silver Surfer anyone?). Considering all the hatred and
lacklustre talk surrounding this film, upon reflection on home release,
Fantastic Four isn't actually "that" bad.

It's certainly not a good film, actually it's very far from it but in
2015 there were a lot of seriously bad movies and at least for lack of
a better word, Fantastic Four tried. It's not the usual action set
piece after action set piece comic book film we've grown to know and
love and then grow tired of and Trank and his team clearly had some
decent ideas.

Bursting onto the scene with his found footage Sci-Fi Chronicle, the
once bright career of Trank seems destined to be clouded in controversy
after his efforts here but there are moments of genuine cinematic
quality. The way in which our fantastic team of unsuspecting super
powered humans discover their abilities is effective and the casting
seems mainly on point.

We all know the talents of Whiplash's Miles Teller, Fruitvale Station's
and Creed's Michael B. Jordan and the likes of Jamie Bell, Kate Mara
and Toby Kebbell are no slouches but whoever in the end edited,
constructed and wrote this film killed Fantastic Four's chances to fly
with some of the most poorly designed editing, character development
and plot advancements in recent memory and not once do we feel any real
connection with these people or believe that they share any form of
chemistry whatsoever and the films aforementioned final act is
bewilderingly bad, the only excuse it would have would be the studio's
so called interference.

It's somewhat of a shame we will never get to know just what ruined
this glum and often more dramatically natured Fantastic Four outing
that at the end of the day has nothing even remotely memorable about it
other than the fact it's so downright lacking in energy,
humour/lightness and a seemingly lack of effort.

The cast was there and no doubt willing but due to a raft of seemingly
powerful situations this film ended up being a real non-event,
certainly not as unwatchable in its terribleness that many would've had
us believe, but certainly a messy, sporadically entertaining attempt at
finally making the Fantastic Four a viable big screen staple.

The Good:
Reed and Ben's friendship is sweet and feels genuine. The approach to the scientific side of this movie is interesting, eventhough it wastes too much of the running time. 

The Not-so-Good:
There's a good movie hidden inside this disappoinment, had it not been made solely to keep a copyright from reverting to its original owner. The flow feels dull and boring, and takes too long to get into exciting action. It doesn't really need another reimagined origin story, and should have focused more on the dynamic between the characters. Very underwhelming action scenes, with weak CGI. What a waste of Doom, this is the 2nd time FOX can't get the famous supervillain correctly, this time turning him into a lame weird looking alien instead of the ruthless dictator genius he should have been. Such a waste of talents too, considering the actors are rising star with proven acting chops. Many of the plot developments do not get proper conclusion, making this feels like a giant intro/teaser for a sequel that might or might never happen.

Oh man. This film is bad in almost every way a film can be. 

For starters, it features a wildly unengaging, uneventful, and flat out dull opening 45 minutes that seeks to introduce us to the characters before they gain their superpowers. This segment isn't necessarily horrendously written or poorly acted, it's just unnecessarily long and covers ground that could probably be covered in 10-15 minutes of a more efficient and interesting movie. 

And then...the movie goes off the rails in a major way. After trudging through the intro, the film hits the gas pedal for what ends up being an equal amount of time of sloppy storytelling, cliche action, and laughable dialogue. With the film's villain not really showing up until the final 20ish minutes one can only wonder at the thought process that led to this final piece of work. Or maybe there wasn't any thought at all. Either way, I want these 90 minutes of my life back.

Absolutely Abysmal.

There are few redeeming qualities in a film like this. Everything from the altered plot line, the characterization, and the lack of any emotional quality, makes this possibly the worst Marvel (and cinematic) entry of 2015.

I for one, am really tired of writers trying to modernize or change classic comic stories, to better suit the audience. They assume that we want something updated, with lots of CGI, and twists and turns along the way. Simpler is always better. The original stories are classic, and beautiful to begin with. The genius struggle of Richard trying to prevent humanity from destroying itself, and from outside threats. The depth of love Susan has for him and the family they build together. Ben's emotional state when he knows there is no going back to his original body, and of course the positvity that the Human Torch carries for the team even in the heat of battle. They were full of struggle and strife, sacrifice and obsession, and a willingness to do good. This movie brings none of those feelings to the screen. The plot is so terribly altered from the original that it makes no effort to connect to it's origin. Everything falls flat.

The actors are so young by comparison to the characters in the comic, that I felt no real empathy towards them. Reed was a genius at birth, but no scene in this film brings about any depth of his intelligence. He's foolish, unintelligent, over-dramatic, and has very little ability to emote (considering Miles Teller's performance in Whiplash). The other characters (2 of which are just CGI monsters) are fairly one dimensional, and lack any real feeling of unity between them as a team. How they managed to do this with one of pop-culture's super families is beyond me.

Truth is, this is what happens when you have poor writing, poor direction, poor editing, poor acting, and a large budget with producers with eyes like dollar signs. Fox ruined this one from the get go.

If you're a fan of the comics (or of movies in general), then avoid this movie like the plague.

I wrote a review for Terminator Genysis a while back and talked about how sad the movie made me.  If that made me sad, then Fantastic 4 just is a colossal failure.  Never have I seen a movie so low energy, it's almost shocking like everyone on screen had a lobotomy.  Miles Teller, normally full of sass and energy, is just reduced to a soft spoken teenager (...right) who gets somehow disqualified for his science experiment to work at the Baxter organization.   There he meets the equally dull Kate Mara who really is just  as soft spoken and wearing some odd wig half the time.  I could go on and on and spoil the movie, and really I don't mind since nothing happens.  But nothing makes really any sense.  Why would Doom come back?  What does he gain really to come back and ... destroy Earth?  What if the humans never went back?  Why did Reed run away?  I mean the star is really for just a shame of how interesting this movie could have been.  The transformation back for the boys was an interesting way to tackle the mythology of the F4, but why was Mara out?  Geez.  The more I type the more frustrated I get.

Many people if I only managed to keep a hold of comic book collection I had as a kid I would not have to worry about retirement benefits now, or ever. I turned eight years of age just as Marvel Comics began releasing their flagship series 'The Fantastic Four'. That was my introduction to the set of superheroes and villains that would ultimately become The Marvel Cinematic Universe. There's always been a rivalry between Marvel comics and DC comics and as far as movie rights go Marvel is definitely in the lead. They steadily produce films that are not only critically acclaimed but are embraced by the fan base. They routinely can earn in excess of $1 billion. Unfortunately, the latest Fantastic Four film is not in that much lauded group. Marvel fell upon hard times years ago and had to sell the rights to some of the most successful characters. Among them were Spiderman and the Fantastic Four. This latest attempt to bring the Fantastic Four to the screen is universally seen as a dismal failure and is much as I regret it by favorite comic as a kid has yet another flop movie. Like many novel properties to a successful animated series produced for television primarily targeted at younger children. This quartet of the most iconic heroes in the Marvel Pantheon appears to have a curse upon it as soon as it goes into production is a movie. As a fan I have suffered through numerous attempts ranging from the monumental fail represented by the 1974 Roger Corman attempt. For those interested copies are out there; I have one and after watching this 2015 version of he wants to just to see the only rendition worse than it. The 2005 movie released by Sony now actually is beginning to look good.

One of the most important aspects of a comic book movie to a dedicated fan is continuity with the comic book itself. Although the MCU included many tweaks they fundamentally remain true to the source material. This 2015 movie completely rewrote the story and included a number of rather puzzling changes. As every charter member of the Merry Marvel Marching Society knows the Fantastic Four receive their powers and it took a spaceship beyond the Earth's atmosphere. After getting hit by radiation they crashed and realized they were each changed. Reed Richards gain the ability to stretch his body to now take on elastic composition. Susan Storm could turn invisible and later create invisible force fields at will. Her brother Johnny became the human torch to sustain his body in the living flame. And Reed's best friend, Ben Grimm, was turned into a creature with super strength that appeared to be made out of orange rocks. Although the basic changes were retained here that is just about the only thing that survive between the comic to this movie.

Reed Richards (Miles Teller) is first seen as a young boy already a genius. While other kids are making baking soda volcanoes for the great school science fair Reed is already working on a transport device. He crosses paths with Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell, who has an innate mastery of anything mechanical and to spend every waking moment perfecting the device. Finally, and another science fair the pair catch the eye of the renowned scientist, Dr. Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathey), and his adopted daughter Susan (Kate Mara). Bracken also has a biological son, a rather wild child, Johnny Karen with a penchant for illegal street racing. Many saw the decision of making Franklin and Johnny African-American as a contrived not to political correctness. Dr. Storm happens to be the director of a he Baxter Foundation, a government-funded research and development Institute. Reed is often intermediate appointment and put to work on the most difficult project, a quantum gate. When this works be a portal to a planet in another dimension. The work had previously been done by Dr. Storm's previous most brilliant student, Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell). His family should've changed the surname generations ago. Together Reed and Victor manage to get the device working just as the ready to do an unauthorized test Reed brings Ben in for the initial trip. They talk Susan into working the controls as the three young men, dimensions to Planet Zero. There they discover the strange green substance with energetic yet volatile properties. Given notice of every strange substance is always green? They rush to get back to the transport pod but Victor is trapped in the substance and has to be left behind. Just as a return everything explodes enveloping, Reed, Ben and Susan in a strange radiation.

At this point most diehard fans of The Fantastic Four or close to reverting to a catatonic state with their loved ones urging, it's going to be a right to stop watching." Having been getting a review copy I felt obligated to continue on reluctantly, I did. The each at the powers is supposed to Reed escape from the facility runs off the grid. The remaining three men to control their powers with Johnny making the most of being a human flamethrower and Susan able to fly around in an invisible force field bubble. Ben receives the fate that is similar in all incarnations of the story turning into the Rocky orange creature. He understandably has some anger management issues which may have been exacerbated by the fact that he appears to be a eunuch. Most times the Thing gets to wear a set of trunks but in this film he stomps around au natural, yet another point of contention for within watching this film. The military steps in and recognizes Ben as a weapon of precision destruction. They are just about to do the same with Johnny and eventually Susan. She uses her innate ability for pattern recognition and locates Richards. When he returned to planet zero they find that Victor has had his environment suit merged with his body and he now has the ability to control energy and matter.

One of the things that bother comic books back from the movies was that the special effects necessary to do justice to the characters had yet to be invented. Finally special-effects has reached the point where Spiderman threads no longer look like silly string and Reed's elastic limbs can retain a realistic look. In many public statements the director, Josh Trank, an original version that he is certain would've gone it rave reviews. Unfortunately the screenplay that was used was written by Jeremy Slater and Simon Kinberg. The latter had been heavily involved in writing most of the X-Men franchise while the former is only one previous script, 'The Lazarus Effect', a sci-fi thriller that was lackadaisical he received. The director, Mr. Trank has one previous film to his name, 'Chronicle', about teenagers that gain superpowers in a rather done, taut thriller, 'The Kill Point', Featuring Donnie Wahlberg and John Leguizamo. That is out on DVD and is definitely worthwhile purchasing. I have no doubt that this was an honest attempt by all involved create reimagining one of the most classic stories and comic books. It represents an attempt to use recent discoveries in quantum physics and to completely reconfigure the interpersonal dynamics. Johnny seems to resent Susan at the adopted kid becomes daddy's favorite resulting in him acting out. Reed is the prototypical socially inept genius nerd that Susan eventually turns to basically on the rebound from the self-centered and abrasive personality of Victor. All this romantic triangle is present in many incarnations of the story just isn't utilized as well as it could be here. In the third act the special-effects crew takes over the story completely. This is a major departure from what fans of comic book movies have come to expect thanks in large part to the overwhelming success of the MCU. People now expect a fully developed story complete with well integrated character development. We have moved far beyond the point where special-effects in the expected to draw the movie. It should add nuance story not its motivation. Hopefully the rights will revert back to Marvel and finally see it done correctly.

Fantastic Four          Dir: Josh Trank

  I know in a lot of people's reviews they always ask the question, "what happened?" It's a generic question that I can honestly say sums up the newest rendition of Fantastic Four. I followed this movie last year from inception to cast and crew choices all the way up to release and...I really wanted this to succeed and prove the naysayers wrong. I wanted to point my finger into the collective chest of everyone who said this wouldn't work and would fail. Well, I sit a broken man feeling like I've been a part of some great rebuke by FOX studios. Fantastic Four is just a cash grab. A last ditch effort to keep competitor Marvel studios away from the first family of comics. With this I hope they relent and let Marvel have at least this bit of their toys back.
  The story of Fantastic Four is a drawn out, science based look at the origins of the teams story. Reed Richards (Miles Teller) and Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell) master interdimentional travel by their senior year of high school and are recruited by Dr. Storm and his daughter Sue Storm (Kate Mara) and they bring Reed and Ben to the Baxter building so Reed can get his further education and bring this design and dream to fruition. Reed also meets the antisocial personality disorder rebel Victor von Doom (Tobey Kebbel) as well as Sue's brother and master craftsman JaltetaStorm ( Michael B. Jordon).
  Upon finishing the project and finding out the asshole government is taking it away Reed, Ben, Johnny, and Victor get trashed and decide to go to earth zero as its been labeled. Things obviously go horribly wrong over there and everyone except Victor makes it back to earth with some slight genetic alterations. What follows is the team learning their powers to be possibly used by the government, Reed runs away leaving everyone behind for awhile. Until they return to the other planet and bring back Doom who looks a little rough but instantly (in the last 25 mins that he needs to destroy the earth so "his world" can prevail. 
  The story is has a schizophrenic pace to say the least. It starts out slow introducing everyone and the time travel mcguffin, immediately picks up to get us to the other planet and give everyone their powers and set up the team is in turmoil arc (that's 50 mins into a 99 min movie. Then trot along to show powers, find Doom and instantly nose dive into the third act like a falling plane. 
  My positives are that the Thing Ben Grimm himself looks phenomenal, that's ho CG should work and Dooms look and power of exploding people's heads through thought is just awesome. I just wish Kate Mara's obvious wig didn't stick out like a red head at a blonde convention, it's lazy and I haven't seen a wig job that bad since Samurai Cop. 
  I am deeply let down by this film but from all the backstage antics, politics, and hearsay it seemed like a project doomed to fail before release and I can see why. 
  Is Fantastic Four the worst superhero movie ever..!? No, not by a long shot unless we forget Elektra, Daredevil, Ghost Rider, Captain America (1990) Superman 3 and 4 among others. This movie is nowhere near the top tier of movies and falls short of the middle tier, but it's just above the bottom tier to offer a slight "you need to at least watch it" recommendation. I won't buy it or watch it again that's for sure but I'm glad I saw the movie dubbed."Trank-gate" and made it out in one piece.

Everyone in this movie, and myself included, just looked bored to be in this movie. It's hard to strip charisma from one of the most charismatic young actors working right now Miles Teller who just seems like a generic actor with the weight loss for the role and the limited range offered from the screenplay. Michael B. Jordan also is stripped of all charisma he has, Jamie Bell is just a block of wood, and Kate Mara just seemed like an after thought when it came to the writing. Toby Kebbell played one of the most menacing villains of 2014 with his stand out performance in Dawn of the Planet of the Apes and does a total 180 playing the least menacing villain in the past few years with 0 character motivation and ugly costume designs. Tim Blake Nelson and Reg E. Cathey do the best they can as talented character actors attempting to overcome the thoughtless script. I just don't understand how someone as talented as Josh Trank that made an amazing movie called Chronicle in 2012 with Jordan can make such a lifeless movie like this. The visual effects are awful especially for Jamie Bell and Toby Kebbell, the score is just outrageous and seemed like it was recycled from other terrible action movies, and the cinematography does not help making every image as boring as the writing. This movie just feels like a 2 hour series premiere to a TV show for Fantastic Four but even a pilot of a TV show would actually give some decent tries at not writing lazy dialogue and not doing an 11 year time jump that comes out of no where and resorts to just rushed plot to get to the climax of this movie that also has 0 motivation. This movie makes the 2005 Fantastic Four seem like a romp (which it most certainly is not minus Chris Evans who you might as well have given an Oscar to compared to Jordan's performance). BORING

Review:
What a load of rubbish! None of the new characters have the screen charisma as the original ones and the whole dark, gloomy feel of the movie, just didn't work. I totally got fed up with the technical jargon, which took up the first hour of the film and the movie seemed to jump from when they got there powers to them being used as weapons by the US government, so you don't see them exploring with there newly found powers. The "Thing" looked like a total mess and Doom just looked like a man in a suit with green eyes. The chemistry between the characters was also pretty bad, until they come together at the end and you don't really get to see any detail, because of its dark look. The storyline lacked wit and I got fed up with the stupid teleporting machine, which took up most of the movies concept. I'm glad that I got that off of my chest! Anyway, best friends Reed Richards (Miles Teller) and Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell) have been working on a prototype teleporter since childhood and during a demonstration, they get the attention of Dr. Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathey), whose the director of the Bacteria Foundation, a government sponsored research institute for young prodigies. Reed gets invited to join Storms squad, which includes his adopted daughter, Sue Storm (Kate Mara) and his son Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), to complete a Quantum Gate, which was originally designed by the wayward Victor von Doom (Toby Kebbell). Victor eventually joins the team, especially when he hears that Sue is on board and after a successful experiment, the facilities supervisor Dr. Harvey Allen (Tim Blake Nelson) plans to send a group from NASA to venture into a parallel dimension called Planet Zero. As Reed, Sue, Johnny and Victor came up with the initial idea for the machine, they decide to make the first journey to Planet Zero but Sue decides to stay behind to guide them. Reed recruits his best friend, Ben to join them on the journey and when they reach Planet Zero, they see some weird green lava, which Victor attempts to touch and causes it to erupt. Whilst running for there life's from the green lava, Victor is left behind because of the collapsing landscape and the others are brought back to earth by Sue, who overrides the controls. They then realise that they have super human powers, due to the explosion that happened in there ship while they were trying to escape from the lava and they are placed in government custody for further testing. Reed can stretch like rubber, Sue can become invisible and generate force fields of energy, Johnny can fly and turn into fire and Ben is a giant rock type figure who has amazing strength. Reed escapes from the facility and tries to find a cure for his friends while Johnny Storm is being used as a weapon for the government. After being in hiding for a year, Sue tracks down Reed and Ben is sent to bring him back to the facility. Now, with there new enhanced suits, they head back to Planet Zero to try and find a cure for there powers and they find Victor who has all of there powers along with telekinetic abilities, so they bring him back to facility, only to find out that he wants to destroy earth so he can rebuild Planet Zero in his image. Victor uses his powers to kill scientists and soldiers, including Dr. Allen and Professor Storm and he returns to Planet Zero with the four scientists in pursuit. Now under the name of Doom, Victor activates a portal that begins to consume the landscape of earth. He is then confronted by the four and after getting beaten down by Doom, they join forces and Ben punches Doom into the portals energy beam while Johnny closes the portal. When they return to earth, they are awarded for there heroics, with a huge operational base and they decide to call themselves the Fantastic Four. Sounds good on paper but it was complete rubbish. I must admit, the first franchise was a bit childish, with some unrealistic concepts but it was much better than this. At least they had some decent actors! With all of these studios rebooting there comic book franchises, after the success of the darker Batman, I'm not surprised that they wanted to reboot the Fantastic Four but they made a right shambles of it. Due to hype, it made a decent profit at the box office which proves that a movie doesn't have to be good to make money. Anyway, they really need to go back to the drawing board with this one because the whole thing was a right mess. Awful!

Round-Up:
This movie was directed by Josh Trank, 31, who brought you Chronicle in 2012. For his second project, I think he took on a franchise that really needed someone with some more experience and he over complicated the storyline when he really didn't have to. Everyone is familiar with the history of the Fantastic Four so he didn't have to come up with a technical reason for there powers. If he does come out with a sequel, he really needs to concentrate on the characters more that the technical references, which are really not that interesting.

Oh you better *believe* I'm going on the rant... Having never been into comics, least of all Fantastic Four, I had no preconceived notions or expectations of the 2004 movie with the same title other than knowledge of it's cheesy premise- but things like that had been grandly overcome before by great writers, directors and actors.  Remember, before Tim Burton did the epic original Batman film, most people associated Batman with... well, Robin and the goofball 1960's Adam West television show.  But then I saw the previews for 2004's Fantastic Four.  And I knew exactly what to expect- a horrible attempt to cash in easy on the rise of comic-based movies and a Taco Bell cross-promo.  Inexplicably, I watched it at some point in the next few years and confirmed my hypothesis.  Years went by, the superhero films got better and smarter and sharper and even ventured into "all-time greatest films" territory with a few poor exceptions (cough..Superman, Green Lantern... Green Hornet.. stupid Spiderman reboot).  Right when this genre was becoming almost unbreakable, the most baffling preview: an unwelcome reboot of a dismal movie nobody asked for, f*cking Fantastic Four... Perhaps even more baffling is that I knew exactly what to expect from every inch of the reel this time and AGAIN found myself watching a terrible movie called Fantastic Four all the way through.  Even Taco Bell should be ashamed for banging this promo prostitute again.  I have nothing else to say about Fantastic Four.  Ever.

During my youth I spent many hours next door with the neighbor boy. Not just for having fun or horsing around, but also because in their veranda there was a disused closet with sliding doors where you could always find some old comics lying around. I suppose these were from the older brother who was a real comic fan. Many hours I spent sitting in front of that closet, reading them all. Comics like "Archie the man of steel", DC comics and of course Marvel. My favorite was "The Fantastic Four". This series I found extremely fascinating and that because it was a collective, consisting of several superheroes with different super powers. They formed a close-knit family and their identity was known to the population so these heroes had a rather family character. Actually, they were a little bit the forerunners of "The Avengers" and the figure of "The Hulk" resembled that of Ben.

Unfortunately, this film is labeled as an unnecessary and worthless reboot. I partially agree with that. The only thing is that I can't judge whether this is an unnecessary reboot or not. I've never seen the previous films made in 1994 and 2005. Saying this is a failure or total disaster though, is something I don't fully agree with. A big part of the film I enjoyed watching and personally I thought it was interesting enough. The introduction of the various members of the unprecedented four was extremely captivating. The beginning showed a young Reed Richards (Judge Owen). A genius who seemed to come from Mars, according to some of his classmates, and who's building a futuristic machine in the garage. A missing component he finds on a junkyard where he bumps into young Ben Grimm (Evan Hannemann). The experiment proves to be a success and things can be materialized to an unknown destination and brought back again. Years later Reed (Miles Teller) and Ben (Jamie Bell) attend a science fair, where they attract the attention of Dr. Storm (Reg E. Cathey) and his daughter Sue (Kate Mara). And before they know it, they are in a sophisticated lab rebuilding their invention on a large scale.

This introduction was the most successful part for me. It felt like an adventure film in which a boy pursues the realization of a dream. In an amateurish and childish way, the prototype of something big is made out of junk (a bit like in "Project Almanac"). Also the introduction to the various members who become part of "The Fantastic Four" in the Baxter Foundation, made this film different of other superhero movies. Mostly this part is kept short so they can move on to the action part immediately. The moment things start going wrong with the four noticing something happened to their bodies after they've jumped to the other dimension (while being drunk), it's still interesting enough. You witness how each of them discover their new capacities. But when the action-packed part of the film starts, it's no longer fantastic. It turns into an uninspired, quickly made up heroes-movie. As if they suddenly realized that stuff should be in it too. The visuals of the other dimension are still enjoyable, but the final stage feels rather flat and not very original. And certainly because nowadays as a moviegoer, you're buried under tons of superhero-movies.

Ultimately, this film emphasizes the formation of and relationships between the members of "The Fantastic Four". The superhero action that you ultimately expect, is fairly limited. A film that takes 90 minutes, with only a demonstration of superpowers and a final clash of fifteen minutes, can hardly be seen as a superhero movie. Perhaps this change was welcome anyway, after all the Marvel releases in recent years. The fatigue comes into play when it's about this genre. Perhaps the final part of the movie wasn't so great, but it wasn't painfully bad either. And now I'll just wait for "Deadpool" ....

9% on Rotten Tomatoes is SO WRONG.  (Ps mild spoilers ahead)

Yes, this film is clearly butchered and it's a real shame because it has so much going for it. I kept watching thinking to myself, "so when exactly does this turn terrible?"-- and it isn't until they go back to the Negative Zone with Doom (I mean, Planet Zero) that the movie really starts to show where it has been cut up like a Beverly Hills Housewife.

For someone who knows little about about the Fantastic Four comics, I think this movie is largely dare I say it... GOOD! For what it is, that is, which is a visibly tortured script without a second or third act fleshed out, and a villain that had hardly any screen time. Sad.

It's got a pretty great first act but it just builds to such a rushed ending that it makes the film feel more like an extended series episode than a movie.

People are upset with how Dr. Doom was handled, but I thought the design of him looks pretty cool, and all his lines as Doom seem in line with his character. Although they go with the Ultimate Universe where he has powers, and I know that people are dying to see Doom portrayed instead as an evil Batman type approach, you can't deny his level of power is still pretty impressive- and good for the studio for at least allowing him to be portrayed with a Dr. Manhattan level of power. The willingness to show multitudes of head explosions that Marvel hasn't dared let be seen quite before lest it become a film for anyone but kids, is a good move towards having a more varied kind of genre film that caters to the gritty side of the super powered movie.

37 minutes cut out of Fantastic Four. I don't know what the true backstory is for what happened upon the making of this, but clearly there suffered huge problems in how to handle it, and this is an issue that happens far too often.

That could be 1/4 of the movie taken out which could have filled in the pacing and layout of the story and its characters and their relationships to each other. Could it have really been that superfluous to edit out of the final cut? And will we ever get to see that footage? Who knows. I am certainly aching to though.

The acting is well done, the dialogue and emotions are realistic, the seeds of the relationships are somewhat present, it is cinematically shot, the special effects are up to snuff, and what actual footage is there is well edited- so is a too rushed ending, a lack of Victor's background information and some artistic liberties in appearances really worth such a ridiculously low score?

The online mockery of this movie is unfounded and simply untrue- it is certainly not the worst comic book movie ever made. I would give it at least a 50%, at least. I thought it was pretty intense at times, and entertaining as a whole- that all counts for a lot more than 9% in my book. It was just disappointing to be searching for its flaws the entire time and then seeing where it goes wrong. I really do wish the additional footage will be released when it comes out on DVD. I am quite curious to see what was excluded, and how it would affect the quality of the theatrical cut. I would give it a 6.5/10

Everything in this movie is half-baked. It's as if the filmmakers thought a movie would just form on it's own out of the ether if they jotted down several ideas on a napkin. Had any of the plot points been fully developed, this might have been pretty good. Well, except Dr. Doom. There's simply no excuse for what they did to that character.

While the rebooted series brought us great promise and potential, the film is horribly disorganized. There are many randomly assembled collection of made up oddities that make no sense whatsoever; Victor von Doom is not shown to be a colleague of Reed Richards, Susan Storm happens to be an adopted daughter of Johnny and his father, and the list can go on and on. There's no bad guy, there's no development of the characters, and for the most part, all we see is how the characters are experimenting with their powers. It seems more like a 100 minute movie trailer than an actual film. 

The original series fared much better because there was a clearer plot line albeit failed to connect the dots properly. I give this movie 1/5 stars.

in spite of the heap of negative reviews, we decided to risk a buck fifty and rent this film from Redbox. Considering that we enjoy comic book films, we figured it couldn't be that bad. I feel I deserve a refund of at least two dollars after having seen it.

In short, the plot moves slowly when it ought to gloss over things, then tells about the exciting bits by glossing over them in quick recap. Even as they did so, we were all shouting at the screen that the parts they just brushed over might have made an interesting movie. But no.

Instead, they drag out the non-super backstory, hurry the middle, then skip to a decidedly NON-climactic climactic conclusion. The only saving grace here is that the special effects are pretty good.

Beyond that, it's a dull story, boring acting, bleak setting, confused plot, and a general waste of time. I can't find much to say about this movie to recommend it. I guess if you're not too picky on movies?

Family friendly notes: lots of action and angst. A few scary moments. The middle gets a bit "PG-13" with people getting kind of exploded and burned. Not sure why they went so grisly right out of nowhere, but considering how down-tempo and dark the movie was, it was only a matter of time. Language throughout and a rude gesture. Side note: what's up with Hollywood adopting the other "D" word as the new bad word of choice?

The Fantastic Four reboot was widely savaged by critics and audiences alike.  It's a shame, since the character development of the titular heroes, the special effects, and the updates to the old origin story weren't bad at all.  The script could have definitely used a lot of polishing, especially to clean up the often-cheesy dialog.  Most bothersome is the pacing, which takes almost half of the movie's short 100 minute runtime to give the heroes their powers.  Doctor Doom's screen time is too short, depriving Marvel's biggest, baddest villain of the screen presence he deserves.

This proves that when the executives and the director don't trust each other and try to pressure one another, the damage always falls on the final cut,  but what's the most frustrating is that it had the potential to be a great sci fi/ superhero movie and i sense it but i just didn't see it. Occasionally a director comes a long and throws the rule book out of the window, refusing to compromise and making a film purely on his own terms. When it works we are treated to such gems as Pulp Fiction.  When it doesn't work we end up with films like Fantastic Four.

The thing to bear in mind with directors who refuse to compromise is that the reason they do things their own way is that they have to, in order to get the film made that they want to make.

Josh Trank (Cockney Rhyming slang) however appears to have taken the decision to throw the Fantastic Four rule book out of the window for absolutely no discernible reason other than self-promotion.  Firstly he decided that the blonde haired blue eyed all American Johnny Storm (The Human Torch) would now be African American.  Now, if this decision is necessary to tell the story Trank wants to tell, then that's fine, but it isn't.  There is no need within the narrative of the story for Johnny Storm to have changed race, and it is made even more confusing by the fact that his sister, Sue Storm (The Invisible Girl) remains a blonde Caucasian (well I say blonde, she actually has magic hair which changes colour, but we'll come to that later).  You wouldn't re-boot Shaft and cast a Caucasian actor in the title role, so why do the opposite when it serves no purpose?

Secondly, still on the subject of meaningless changes of colour, we shall mentioned The Thing.  The Thing is orange, he has always been orange, but in this film he is grey.  A rather dull and boring grey that serves perfectly a metaphor for the film itself.  Again, as with Johnny Storm, there is no explanation for this change in colour, nor is the different colour necessary to serve any narrative purpose.  

Throwing the rule book out of the window is fine of course if you are Tarantino, but Trank delivered to 20th Century Fox a two hour and forty minute film.  You have to wonder how bad this film was as Fox decide to do two things.  Firstly they cut the running time down to one hour forty minutes, losing an entire hour. Secondly they replaced a lot of what was left of Trank's footage and decided to order re-shoots without the director's knowledge, permission, or input.  The one hour and forty minutes that Fox released is a dull pointless and uninteresting mess that serve only to fulfill one purpose,  to teach generations of future film makers exactly how not to go about the process of making films.  

The first fifty minutes is dedicated to giving us the new origin story.  Now in a two hour and forty minute film devoting the first fifty minutes to the origin story would make sense, but when the running time is reduced to one hour and forty minutes, the origin story now takes up 50% of the entire film, leaving little left for storytelling.

Also, by taking out an entire hour of running time Fox leave no time for either action or superheroing.  It has been reported that Fox cut three action scenes from the original edit.  Quite why you would do this when you are attempting to make a super hero action film is strange, and particularly frustrating as the final result is that, apart for the climatic final scene, there are no other action scenes in the film.  

The other major problem with the film is the cast:-

Miles Teller (Reed Richards) appears to be the only person in the film who actually seems able to act. This problem is compounded by the fact that once we come to the end of the fifty minute regeneration story Reed disappears for half of the rest of the film, only coming back in the last 25 minutes climax.

Michael B Jorden (Johnny Storm) Trank describes the character of Johnny Storm as "smart, hilarious and charismatic" which is strange as Michael B Jorden skill fully manages to portray absolutely none of these qualities.  

Kate Mara (Sue Storm)  The blame for this one has to land squarely in the lap of Fox.  Trank wanted to cast someone else, but Fox insisted that Kate Mara play Sue Storm.  Mara commented that she wanted to make Sue Storm "As real as possible", she didn't.  Mara's performance is not one dimensional as a one dimensional performance at least has a dimension, Mara's performance has none.  Her portrayal makes Sue Storm one of the blandest, dullest and least interesting characters in the history of cinema.  The only interesting thing about Mara is her hair which switches between a light brown with blonde highlights to bright yellow blonde wig which she wore during the re-shoots.  Not only does this $5 wig look like it is made of straw but it is a full 15cms longer then her actual hair.  Why would spend $120 million on a film, and then ruin it by giving one of the title characters a crap $5 wig is anyone's guess.

Jamie Bell (Ben Grimm)  To be fair to Bell it is hard to know if he can actually act, as he isn't actually asked to do any acting. He looks a bit grumpy, says a few lines, and then is replaced CGI version of his superhero persona.

Toby Kebbell (Victor Von Doom)  Normally Victor is portrayed as the dictator of a fictitious eastern European country, adding gravitas and foreboding to his menace.  Here Trank gives us a Victor Von Doom who is just a socially dysfunctional greebo who spends his times sat in his room playing computer games and cracking one out off over his unrequited love, and it doesn't take a grates deal of working out to figure out who she is, as there is only one female character in the entire film.

There are numerous other issues with the film, but if I were to address them all it would take longer for you to read the review than it would to watch the film, so I won't as you have much more important and interesting things to do like alphabetise your DVD collection, iron your towels, or have a quick Trank.

Suffice to say that Fantastic Four, whilst never the most sought after cinematic franchise, is now well and truly soiled goods and Fox should take a leaf out of Atari's book and rather than release the DVD's, they should just bury them in the New Mexico desert.

Oh and BTW, that scene in the Trailer where The Thing dive bombs out of a plane, that's not in the film.
There are hints of great things, but mostly just a dark and dreary mess. Stupid and boring. You have to see it to believe how horrible it is. It's biggest tragedy is that it had so much potential.

So, this got a lot of hate, but I think I like it better than Avengers 2, which for me was very dull, confusing mash up and I can't even recall the story because it wasn't very memorable.  And some of the CGI of A2 was embarrassingly bad. So, relative to Avengers 2 and relative to say, the original FF movies, I liked it.  It definitely was lacking a little life - that would have been easy to add -  a little more humor and chemistry and interaction.  And, for sure, Ben Grimm, please put on some shorts.  That was awkward.  But, I think this was the right direction to go with FF in general.  Good tone, villain was pretty good, overall story was pretty good.  I liked it better than where x-men movies have gone - I am ready for x-men reboot.  

Thing to remember about superhero movies - the powers of the characters are almost like characters in their own right and need good screen time and presentation.  They did ok in this movie, but didn't really take advantage of what they COULD have done.  The old FF movies, while painfully campy and poorly cast IMO, did great job at portraying human torch's powers, the silver surfer was amazing and one of the best on screen looking characters in the MU.  Ben Grim's rubber suit was unwatchable though, 

I liked this cast better and Thing (with the addition of some Under Armor gear) was good.  But they don't really let their powers shine.  Miles Teller's powers were portrayed in a cool way, not a silly way, which i liked.

I liked it, kind of wish they were doing sequel, but if Marvel gets it, that may end up being best thing in the end.  I don't like Fox making their movies in a MU vacuum.

Is this the worst superhero movie ever? No.
However, I hadn't seen a film derail its plot in its final act this badly since Superman IV.
Up until then, the film had some potential, with a good cast. Apart from several terribly silly leaps in logic, the film had an interesting plot about inter-demtional travel, which felt like it could have been a film on its own. 
However, the character development is rushed and underdeveloped and once they arrive at planet zero, the planet is a let down. Like much of the film, it is restricted to in its scope, and we see just one small area. Instantly things happen, so they run back to Earth. We then get a brief run down of the transformation of the characters, then the film runs back to trying to rebuild the way back to planet zero. We already saw that. The film needed to move elsewhere from here. Maybe to the Fantastic Four. That would have been an idea. But no. 
The plot line of the government using the four as weapons is given little time, with no in depth analysis of the effect of being put into war zones and killing humans on our young superheros. Again, it's just glossed over and not mentioned until the final moment.
Then, when they return to planet Zero, we encounter Dr Doom. And it's from here that the film feels like the last 15 minutes of Superman IV, where the whole plot of Nuclear Man setting off a nuclear war and Superman having to prevent world destruction and beat a villain who had already had the better of him, was cut out, leaving him to just move the moon, drop Nuclear Man in a reactor, and give a quick speech and then fly past and smile at the camera. The film feels like it's missing so much, and that's what happens here in F4.
It's amazing how rushed the ending is. The film hadn't been great to that point, but a proper ending would have left the film as a solid 5/10 sort of film, and at least given hope to the series. Instead, the film is so hacked apart, leading to the critical outcry that occurred across the internet, leading to no hope of a Fantastic Four movie in the near future.
The cast are okay, but they have very little time to do anything. Maybe one day, the directors cut will get released and we will see a much better Fantastic Four, but its unlikely. Fox really dropped the ball with this one.

Fant4astic will be hailed as one of the worst comic book movies of all time.  The reboot to an already weak franchise is Dull, boring, and just plain lazy.

The first half of the film is actually pretty damn good, trying a more subdued, serious and dark take on the source material. But the moment the characters get their powers halfway through the movie everything just falls apart. Character motivations make no sense, compared to the slow pace of the first half the second half feels rushed, the way Dr. Doom is handled is laughably bad, the climax is underwhelming and honestly quite boring, and the dialogue after Doom comes back into the picture is absurdly, laughably bad. Watching the film the problems with its production couldn't be any more obvious - it's like halfway through you begin watching a completely different movie. I honestly would be interested to see what Josh Trank's intended vision was and if it would've fully committed to the subdued and serious tone of the first half since the film's biggest problem is that it tries to be both a serious sci-fi film and a fun comic book action film at the same time. These two styles don't go together - pick one and commit! Honestly it's impossible for me to hate or even dislike this movie - it's absolutely worth watching just for how hilariously confusing a mess it is. This is about as close as you get to watching a director's vision fall apart on screen.

Fantastic Four Review:
Leading up to the release of this film there was a lot of negative buzz surrounding it fuelled by the review embargo which lifts tomorrow. Having now seen the film I can firmly say and you may argue with me the negative buzz is well warranted. Before the last 20 minutes I was willing to give this a 2/5 but alas I cannot. In this review I will cover 4 issues I had with this film.
1. Editing- this film is poorly edited and it shows on screen. A movie should flow and transition seamlessly into the next scene. Fantastic four does not, instead it feels like a series of vignettes- stilted, showcasing glimpses of a good film.
2. Story Progression/Pacing- relates to editing, the story is smack smack smack with not a lot of logic behind anything. Character development and motivation is horrid with nothing happening until the last 20 minutes of the movie. And spoilers they don't get powers until an hour in.
3. Age- actors who are nearing their 30s playing teens is always a worry- sometimes it's pulled off and sometimes it's not in this case it's the later. Everyone suffers from not making their characters more than one dimensional caricatures bogged down by the un-believability of the ages they are playing.
4. Setting- a problem with movies when they use limited settings is they have to utilise them without them becoming stagnant and tiresome. Fantastic four once again fails in this department bogging it's movie down in a film that relies too much of its setting in a lab and thus warrants many yawns throughout.
In saying that the performances were fine and I really was rooting for this to be a good film despite all the buzz around it but alas it just isn't fantastic.

Okay, so although it's not the worst film ever made, it still might be one of the worst superhero films ever made. That had to have been one of the worst third acts in the history of cinema, and the only milestone that Fantastic Four achieved was the fact that it managed to join the line of other crappy Fantastic Four movies ever made. 

Okay, so in order to keep my sanity, I will keep this review fairly short. To start out, what I actually liked about the movie was the first half. The first half was actually fairly interesting, and the screenplay wasn't so bad. The movie felt like it was building towards something, and at the very least, I was entertained by what I was watching. Also, this movie contains an up and coming cast of stars, such as Miles Teller (Whiplash), Michael B. Jordan (Creed), Kate Mara (The Martian), Jaime Bell (Snowpiercer) and Toby Kebbell (Dawn of the Planet of the Apes). All of these actors have shown that they can act, and they do what they can in this movie. With that being said, let's get down to business. 

This movie was very, very messy. Like I said, the first half was entertaining enough, but that's because it felt like we were building towards something. This movie never really builds towards anything and it felt like half of a movie. The movie spends a good hour building up a decent plot, but throws it all away with an awful second half. I didn't believe that a third act could be so bad until I watched this film, and let me tell you, it was truly was awful. 

The screenplay during the first half was passable, but as the story progressed, it just went straight down the toilet. There are so many ridiculous plot holes in this movie that makes you question your sanity, and it honestly becomes an absolute bore. I'll just take one example from the film, and that would be the formation of the "Fantastic Four". These five people are brought together to crack inter-dimensional teleportation, but realistically, only three out of the five should've been there in the first place. Reed Richards and Victor Doom are both geniuses, and Sue Storm somewhat helps with the process, but the other two characters are there for no reason. They contribute little, if anything to the process and feel wasted. Let's be real, Dr. Franklin Storm put all of his faith in one unknown teenager, his genius daughter, his not so genius son, the muscle bound friend of Reed, and an erotic inventor. Only a God would've know that these people would've formed a perfect team together, which makes the movie so much less believable. 

The visuals in this movie also struggled, as there were many moments where it looked just flat out awful. Even though the special effects lacked and the CGI was bland, the thing that stood out the most to be was Dr. Doom. He was probably the worst looking villain I've seen in a long time, and again, I had to see it to believe it. With a film with an incredibly high budget, I would've expected more out of it, but sadly, what I saw on screen was vastly disappointing.

The editing in this film was also a mess. As if the pacing wasn't bad enough, but many scenes cut off too early which made them feel incomplete. There were many chunks of time that was skipped over in the movie, and with a movie with this high of a budget, I expected a lot more. I don't know if that's the editors faults, or the fact that they had little quality film to work with. This movie could've benefited from an extra 30 minutes of screen time, but then again, that only would've been a benefit if this film was good.

Okay, so most of us cinephiles know about the backstory behind this film, but no one is 100% sure. To sum it up, Josh Trank reportedly had a different vision for this film, but his disagreements with Fox led to a disaster in production. There were re-shoots, scenes were cut out, and the overall plot was tampered with so much that this movie felt so confusing. In my opinion, I've seen Josh Trank direct. He has proven to be an excellent director, and during this film, I could see the glimmers of potential throughout. I think he was aiming for a much darker and gritty style of the Fantastic Four, which I think would've worked perfectly. Since I have no knowledge of which side is at fault, I won't take a side. But, I think this movie's failure can be attributed to many production issues and behind the scene issues. It really felt like multiple people were directing this film, multiple people tried to edit this film, and all of them had different visions for the direction of the movie.

Oh boy. I still have a lot to say, but I will hold it all back before I go mental. 

In all, Fantastic Four probably isn't as terrible as the reviews are making it out to be, but it certainly isn't a good film. Although the first half was passable, the production issues caused a conflict in tone and messy editing. The fantastic actors that this movie had at the helm were wasted, as they had to act their way around a crappy script. The CGI and visuals were awful, and it the visuals should honestly be ashamed of themselves. The third act is probably one of the most abrupt and awful endings in the history of comic book movies, and this movie is definitely not worth buying or renting. If you see it on Netflix or on demand for free, then maybe consider it. Although I'm trashing this movie a lot, it was still watchable at times, and I could see the glimmers of hope that it possessed. In the end, I will not execute this movie, but instead hand it two stars and try and forget about what I just watched.

Fantastic Four makes the lousy 2005 version look like the Best Picture of the year. Josh Trank's reboot is an unforgivable disaster. It's boring, lifeless, listless, unfunny, and not in the least tiniest bit fun. The four actors are talented and have never looked so bored in their entire lives. The direction is beyond atrocious. The screenplay and dialogue are horrendous. This is such a wasted opportunity of a film. CAN SOMEONE PLEASE JUST GET FANTASTIC FOUR RIGHT FOR ONCE?!?!?!

Say what you will about Tim Story's first FF film, at least it had a decent build up that allowed us to connect with the characters and a more organic fit for the team's entry into that world.  Trank's FF had none of that, by the time they were dealing with the main threat it felt like we'd barely had any time with them, their powers, and their new status,

One consistent problem with both Story and Trank's FF films are their poor interpretations of Dr. Doom.  Story made him a cartoonish joke, Trank made him an emotionless uber threat.  The real Doom is somewhere in between, we need someone to get it right for a change; give us the smart, stubborn, and arrogant Doom that makes his comic character so great.
