My views towards superheroes films is similar to that of Disney movies; very complicated, convoluted, and getting tired of their formulas. A main contributor to this is most superheroes films feel the need to tell an origin story, and all feeling the same in outline form. Usually you have a young main character getting into an accident, is a good-doer, and after learning about his new-found abilities becomes a hero for the greater good. Our main character could suffer from blindness, being bullied, or simply being beautiful which limits the type of characters that are created. Superheroes films, at the moment, don't experiment much to the point that female-led superhero films can be counted on a single hand.

Fantastic Four was different for me as director, and writer of the film Chronicle, Josh Trank, brought in new ideas to a genre that refuses to experiment. It was a good film that while limited to the found footage format actually managed to be one of the rare times a found footage film worked. So for the first time since Man of Steel in 2013 I had expectations to experience a different kind of superhero film. Allot of what I learned about the film seem promising, and the teaser trailer got my interest. Now the point I started getting worried about the project wasn't the reshoots since one of my favorite movies, Jaws, and one of the best superheroes film ever made, Superman (1978), also endured reshoots. It was with the first official trailer for Fantastic Four that made me lose interest as the trailer was generic.

You think reviews would have kept me away, except for the fact superheroes films are the least trustworthy for me when it comes to critical, and audience reviews. If "The Dark Knight" is held to the highest standards for many of these reviewers so I had little reliable sources to turn to whenever one of these films get release. So out of the hundreds of reviews for this film the two reviewers I actually trusted with this genre both wrote negative reviews for the film. This caused me to be cautious. Then came in the talk of cut content which is where my interest raised again.

Fantastic Four follows four young outsiders teleported to an alternate and dangerous universe which alters their physical form in shocking ways. The four must learn to harness their new abilities and work together to save Earth from a former friend turned enemy. The first ten minute of the films seem promising showing a young Reed Richard, and Ben Grimm attempting to send a toy car into another dimension. Unlike the rest of the film, the character are enthusiastic towards this goal, and dedicated to achieving it. What's wrong with these first ten minutes are simple. For starter, Ben Grimm "It's Clobberin Time" catch phrase originates from the times his older brother beat him up. Now I, expected this eventually pointless discovering would lead to some sort of repressed memory for Ben Grimm. This film clearly wanted to go in a dark direction so why not repress murder? It wouldn't be pleasant, nor worked well, but would have been different, and explain Ben Grimm lack of social skills or friends in the film.

In the first ten minutes, Reed Richard succeeds in building a teleportation device in his parents garage. Before that though, Reed Richards tells the entire class he wants to be the first person to teleport himself. His teacher, naturally tells him to pick a real career seemingly wanting to crush a young kid dream. I would argue against the realism of this scene, but school is where dreams go to die. My college professor told me that once when I, and several others, talked about our desired career on the first day in class (no joke). So after succeeding in teleporting a toy car what happens to Reed Richard? Fast forward seven years later. Neglecting what could have been interesting events to follow-up on. Why this timeskip is so damaging is plain simple; it glosses over the possible introduction of Reed Richard to the Baxter Foundation at an early age, and meeting the other major characters. If the film chose to show Reed Richard working within the Baxter Foundation at a such young age, and communicating with the other major characters developing the cast could have been easier. Also, I'm expected to buy within the first ten minutes a young kid developed a teleportation device in his parents garage, but a research institute aiming for the same thing completely missed this story in every possible way. This is the moment I gave up hope for good, sensical writing in the film.

In a science competition Reed Richards shows his teacher who told him to pick a real career. Demonstrate in front of his teacher eyes, and hands covering his ears a teleportation device. This same teacher who failed to crush Reed Richard dreams disqualified Reed Richard under the basis he believe Reed Richard perform magic. Yes, because Reed Richard who had his hands covering his ears build a machine in order to make an elaborate light show in order to perform magic. I would argue how this teacher got his job, but the US education system is terrible so it's not far fetch when depicting this teacher.

All of this was meant to develop characters within the first hour. However, that soon evaporate with one major mistake. So in the film Reed Richard, along with other young bright scientists that make up the core cast have to work together to make a teleportation device for the Baxter Corporation within the building. Instead of showing the trial, and error process of making such a machine would be a good excuse to develop characters, and their bond. The film decides to speed up the process by only showing the group talk to each other every now, and then. Not showing any hardship that has to be overcome when building a machine straight out of science fiction. Therefore, the completion of this teleportation device doesn't feel like a group achievement. Feeling more like the writers went through another plot point keep the story rolling.

It might read like I skipped over a lot of material, but the sad truth is hardly anything in the first hour contributes much to the overall picture. The only thing that needs to be brought up is the group decides to go to Planet Zero because they got drunk, and want to stick it to the man by going to this other dimension first. Something goes awry when the group goes to Planet Zero, and eventually return home with one less member. Now, Sue Storm, not going to Planet Zero would have been fine if she didn't get her powers by getting blasted by a computer. At most, a computer will catch on fire, and burn you. There are other side effects, but none of which include the powers to be invisible. To be clear, I'm not referring to Kate Mara (the actress who plays Sue Storm) career after this movie either.

Another issue is, like every live action Fantastic 4 film, is it desire to follow trends for of the time for unexplained reasons. For instance, as unsubtle as a villain like Red Skull in Captain America is, that film doesn't undermined the audience intelligent, and actually plays up on that aspect. Here, there's a character named Victor Von Doom. Hm, there's clearly nothing wrong here. I am one-hundred percent positive someone named Doom will not, in any way, be the villain of the film or turn out to be evil. Noticing this I am dealing with yet, another instance of "Obviously Evil Bad Guy". Unlike in say something like Mad Max: Fury Road where the "Obviously Evil Bad Guy" worked because the aesthetics of the film complemented it. In Fantastic 4 it is attempting to be more realistic (for some reason) where it goes against such a cartoonish name. The film attempts to humanize Dr. Doom by making him difficult to work with, rude to his peers, getting jealous when Reed Richard is talking to his possible crush Sue Storm, and doing stupid things when he is drunk. Wait, some of that is still evil behavior. Well, the writing really sucks for this film.

By the time the second act finally ends you're given enough reasons to dislike the film. The rush pacing, glossing over obstacles, missed opportunity for character development, and failing in setting up a grand story. One aspect that could have been engaging simply goes away due to a time skip. Ben Grimm returns to Earth as a pile of CGI, walking, talking rocks, and when the film shows Ben Grimm in this form for the first time he is scare. However, this turmoil for Ben doesn't last long as soon as he talks to Dr. Allen minutes later he accepts his new body. Well, that was pointless. There's also another scene where Franklin Storm sees his son, Johnny Storm, confuse in pain burning endlessly. Instead of making a somewhat emotional moment of Franklin Storm talking to his son, and calming him long enough for Johnny to be in human form. Viewers are instead greeted with a scene of Reed Richard escaping from a military base that has little security despite the fact they are holding people with abnormal abilities. Though, the film is not entirely to blame for this lengthy review. I got admit I missed an opportunity to make a racist joke as to why Johnny Storm is black in this movie unlike every other incarnation of Fantastic Four.

One line of dialogue in the film pissed me off way more than it will the average movie viewer. It was during a scene where supervisor Dr. Allen is showing footage of The Thing working in military combat fields. At the moment the camera shows The Thing ripping off the upper half of a tank Dr. Allen says "He's been involved in covert operations". Really? A walking, pile of rock has been involved in several covert operations? Not only that, but apparently none of this footage, nor the enemies footage of The Thing has been seen by any form of media? I'm expected to believe , The Thing, existence is unknown to the world when he is shown ripping apart the upper half of a tank, and throwing it at enemy soldiers? Now the reason this line pissed me off was because in my time off I played a video game called Binary Domain. The entire game was meant to be a covert mission, yet in one level I fought against a Spider Robot the size of tall building. This occurred in one level so try to imagine an entire video game spanning around ten hours with events like that. The game events unfold in the span of a couple of days, and of course it eventually get public attention. Yet, I'm expected to believe for an entire year The Thing has been a part of military operations, and none of the enemy soldier that saw him told anyone? Dr. Allen says The Thing saves people while The Thing is hurting people on footage. So if this claim is true, HOW COME THERE ISN'T A SINGLE NEWS REPORT OF SEVERAL SOLDIERS REPORTING THEY SAW A GIANT PILE OF ROCK IN COMBAT! I'm willing to accept any leap of logic, but not, when it is very clear, that the film itself is attempting to be realistic, and wants to be taken seriously to the degree of Fantastic Four.

The final act is entirely ripped from another movie. A generic superhero movie without giving its main villain a motive for destruction, or has heroes that care that a military facility is filled with dead people. Seriously, there's no emotional reaction from the Fantastic Four when ordinary people die. When the Fantastic Four have no chemistry with each other, than showing them be concerned with the fate of planet Earth in the climax there's no sense of weariness from them. At this point in the film, the team isn't even referred to as the Fantastic Four, nor is the name ever uttered in the film. It's ashame of it for some inexplicable reason. What this final act also contains is a force "Save the World" climax, and a weak final fight for some action. When the film actually ends, it becomes evidently clear the film amounted to nothing. From the first hour that set everything to the last act that goes in an entirely different direction. Losing faith along the way before becoming a film that satisfies no one.

The cast of Fantastic Four includes the talented cast of Miles Teller, Kate Mara, Michael B. Jordan, and Jamie Bell. Performances they aren't bad when showing the inner struggle of their characters alone, but together the cast don't have any chemistry together. Jamie Bell, and Kate Mara for instance, never make eye contact with each other in the entire movie. When the Fantastic Four are all together on-screen they don't come across as good friends or a family. One issue being Jamie Bell is absent for a good portion of the film while the other cast member play characters who built a teleportation device. Toby Kebbell who plays Doctor Doom provides a stale performance. As soon as he appears on-screen there's no question he's a villain. He's gets the worst part to play since his costume for Doctor Doom is expressionless, and his mask seems like a crash test dummy head painted black with neon green lights implanted on it. It's look terrible on-screen.

Miles Teller gets a few scenes where his acting chops adds to a scene. For example, there's a scene that requires Miles Teller to crawl to a pile of rubber after an incidents. His display of concern is convincing, but when he turns around to see his body stretched out his mortification sells this moment. It's a good moment in the movie, but this is only of one of about three scene where the characters come across as people. The other two scenes being Jamie Bell voicing his distraught in being The Thing for the first time, and the other being Michael B. Jordan screaming as he is engulfed by flames. These snippets make the character seem real since they are afraid of they new-found abilities they don't understand to use. However, there's where their most human moments end. Unlike other films in the genre, we don't see the Fantastic Four gradually accepting their abilities.

The supporting casts are entirely one note for the film. Reg E. Cathey who plays Franklin Storm maintains a similar facial expression of disapproval for every scene he's in. He's can't do anything in the role. Tim Blake Nelson who plays Dr. Allen has to look smug, and pretend to be chewing gum for every scene he's in. He makes little no lasting impression. That's about it for the supporting cast. Most of the actors in the film appear briefly in a scene or two then never appear again. One of them being Ben Grimm mother, and his brother who disappear after a single scene.

This film contains a few practical effects, and they are convincing looking. Like the mentioned moment when Reed Richard is crawling, and legs stretches out for a couple of meters. CGI on the other hand never blends into with the live action portion. It's rubbery whenever Reed Richards stretches his body in the few moments near the end when powers are used. However, the CGI isn't used for action scenes, nor in moments of showing off the heroes good sides. At most, you'll see briefly clips of The Thing military operations, one brief fight with Reed Richards attempting to fight off military gunman, and towards the end when the Fantastic Four team up to fight Doctor Doom. So very powers usage throughout the world. The Thing looks convincing depending on the lighting, but when he's fully visible isn't convincing. Kate Mara wig changes throughout the film, and so does her style. It's distracting, but the least of the film problems. Planet Zero itself is simply an empty planet with nothing living on it. The music is just forgettable.

Fantastic 4 is a bad film that had potential, but was squandered. It's a shame to be what it originally wanted to be opting to be a film that pleases everyone, and in the end becoming a film no one wants. Some ideas it had could have led to a good movie, and certain moments in the film are inspired, but the whole thing is a big mess. Good talent is wasted, special effects quality are uneven, and the script is weak on all front. In the end, the biggest let down of seeing this film is the only thing that makes it stand out in the genre is how bad it turned out.

A Silly Afterthought:

I had no idea where to include this piece of thought in my review so I just place it here in the end. One thing I noticed about all the Fantastic Four films, and some of the comic books is The Thing always wears pants, but in this film he's always walking naked. So, I find it funny the MPAA considers this PG-13 material, yet something like Steve Jobs has probably like small uses of the F word is rated R. If I understand this correctly, I could display nudity in a movie so long the character is entirely CG, yet simple foul language will get me an R rating. Every movie watcher probably knows this by now, but the MPAA really needs to update their regulations for movie ratings. Oh yeah, there's also the costumes which I didn't comment on. To be honest, I prefer the costumes in this film over the comic books which basically are blue tight suits with a number four on it.

And here we go again, round...errr...whatever, for yet another reboot of yet another comicbook franchise, I hope its a winner. Yeah so after the light-hearted antics of the earlier movies failed to set the box alight way back in 2005 and 2007 (even though they weren't actually that bad), someone decided to give them another whirl. The Four are Marvels first team/family of superheroes and thusly they needed a big budget extravaganza to fit into their new successful universe.

This time things would be different, the jokey, slapstick shenanigans of the earlier movies was gone, long gone, in its place would be a much darker, grittier approach that would breathe new realistic life into the Four. The fact that the Fantastic Four were well known for being a more colourful, light-hearted set of heroes (mainly down to their rather silly super powers), seemed to make no difference to how director Trank wanted to go. This would be the Nolan-esque version of the Fantastic Four that incorporated many of the Fantastic Four comic incarnations, like it or lump it. 

So the idea of trying to cover all comicbook visions for the movie was brave and reasonably sound, instead of just relying on hammy childish humour and action, they would balance that out with a much broodier tone. The characters would be younger, the technology would be more believable, costumes would be more sensible, super powers would be more grounded or shocking like an affliction, and the overall vibe of the movie would be more serious. The plot remains pretty similar to what we already know of the Four with minor changes. Instead of going into space they jump into a parallel dimension and are exposed to dangerous otherworldly energies or substances that cause the super power mutations at a molecular level. What follows is the team slowly coming to terms with their new powers whilst being confined to a secret military base and being abused by the government for special ops. Eventually, of course, they need to come up against the much stronger Dr Doom who was presumed missing in action in the parallel dimension.

Now the start of this movie is actually fine (first half hour or so), it all moves along perfectly well. We get a nice small flashback to a young Ben Grimm and Reed getting to know each other and seeing their interest in science and technology flourish. Moving on from there we jump to a much older Reed and Grimm as they now prepare to jump into another dimension with the machine they helped build along with Doom, Sue Storm, and to a degree Johnny Storm (Johnny Storm is not really required for this, or anything, in any way). Everything I saw in these early sequences was pretty engaging I thought, it all looked good, sounded good and the cast fit their roles well. As we progressed further into the parallel dimension I still found myself enjoying the film. I really liked the visuals, the spacesuit design was cool, the Quantum Gate machine looked both intimidating and functional and planet Zero (parallel dimension planet) was eerie and foreboding. 

Once reaching the real crux of the movie, their super powers, I was quite pleasantly surprised to see a very hard edged approach. Now when I say hard edged, I mean its clearly been crafted in a Cronenberg fashion (as widely reported) with a big body shock element infused into the proceedings. I actually really liked how Trank and co (or whoever) did this, having Sue fluctuate between transparency without control, Grimm being a painful mass of solid rock material with no real shape, just a pile of rubble on the floor. Then you have Johnny also appearing in pain as he writhes around on a table engulfed in flames, and finally Reed strapped to a table, his limbs elongated, muscles pulsing, he doesn't appear to be in pain but unable to control his limbs properly. This angle was pretty daring for a supposed young persons comicbook flick, but it deserves kudos, I think the team behind the film really managed the impossible with such corny super powers, they made them actually believable and emotional, we could feel their fear.

What I also liked, and what also shocked me, was the inclusion of actual minor horror elements in the film. When Doom gets back from planet Zero and starts killing people for no real reason, he does it in a nasty way. He appears to fry them until their bodies pop, or their internal organs explode outward, which ever, but you do see blood! As Doom escapes from the military facility he appears to make peoples heads burst with blood splatterings galore! I did not expect this at all. Unfortunately even though Doom is a badass in the film, his visage does look very rushed as does his attire. He merely seems to be wearing a dark metallic bodysuit and mask with lots of neon green glowing through in places. Apparently his spacesuit had fused with his body but that doesn't really explain why he looks the way he does, how he got his green cloak and hood, nor does it explain his mask and weird mouthpiece (the glowing green was the energy substance found on planet Zero). He basically looks like some kind of metallic, mummified, mannequin, gimp.

Despite the half decent start to the movie things do take a nosedive quite rapidly. The timeline clearly jumps around, different edits, wigs, things aren't really explained too well etc...such as Reed running off and living in Panama for some reason. What the hell was he trying to do? what was the point in that entire sequence?? Characters talk about how Reed has been off the grid for so long and how he's hard to find...yet they just manage to find him really quickly when they decide to hunt him down. And why is it the Four agree to remain in this secret base and carry out special ops? Surely they must know these military government types are just using them and they probably won't find a cure, they all seem pretty naive to me. Then you have this whole other dimension notion, visually effective at least, but none of it is even remotely thought out properly. They reach another planet in another dimension, but it just doesn't come across as that bigger deal. Surely this would open up so many questions about that parallel dimension and that universe, that whole plot angle just seemed way too big for this movie. An entire alternative universe in a parallel dimension! that's some heavy shit! but they use it like some kind of throwaway plot device. Did I mention the wigs aspect?

I still don't really get why Doom wanted to stay in the parallel dimension on planet Zero. OK I understand that the natural raw energy somehow powers him and seems to keep him alive or healthy, but there's nothing there! What the hell is he gonna do on this barren wasteland of a planet forever?? Why does he wanna wipe out Earth all of a sudden? especially if he doesn't even intend to remain on Earth, in our dimension. Oh and how did he know when the team had come back to rescue him? how did he know where they would reappear? maybe it was the same location? Did anyone else also notice that the despite the weather appearing to be really bad and really harsh on planet Zero, it was always very calm with no wind or anything, where ever the characters were.

At the end of the day there just doesn't feel like there's anything at stake here, the finale is set in this desolate wasteland in another dimension, so who cares. The Four never really seem to fully utilise their powers for anything, or anywhere, they just get them...and mope around. Even when they must battle Doom, they still don't seem to be that effective with their powers, but I guess you could say they are still learning (for the sequel eh). Even though I quite liked the start of the movie and I did like the initial body shock reactions of the characters, the entire film is essentially just exposition for the obviously pre-planned sequel which may now never happen. As such, this movie is like a highway to nowhere, exposition that leads to nowhere, Hollywood is so comfortable with this cheeky method/formula now, and its very worrying. You don't get proper movies anymore, you get promises and setups for the following bigger movie, if you're lucky, because as we all know, films always come in trilogies these days.

I liked it.  This was a different take on the classic Fantastic Four origin story, but none the less I liked it.  I still like The Fantastic Four: The Rise Of The Silver Surfer (2007) movie better though.

It's more of a 6.5 for me, but I really had some fun watching it, so I will be generous with a "7" here! I also took a look at the previous one, which came out in the distant 2005! Seemed less time to me, but it's been ten years already! The old one was 5.7 out of 10, which is still too low I think. I would definitely give a 6.5 in the old one as well! The old one did have Jessica Alba and Chris Evans, so comparison falls short on the cast side!

Anyways, bottom line is that if you liked the old one, you will like this one as well, maybe a bit more. This one is closer to my taste, although the Fantastic Four seem younger than their actual age in the comics. I did like the fact that it was kind of darker than the previous one and that it pointed out the emotional roller-coaster and distress of acquiring their powers, whereas in the previous one it was more like "yeah, we have powers, let's be cool and kick ass". 

I really don't get all these people that sit down and compare what was in the comic and what was in the movie, etc, failing to understand that it's not the director's job to transfer the entire comic in the movie, or to attempt to understand what they pictured in their minds when they read the comic and then make a movie with it! For God's sake! 

It's a fair movie, with nice action and interesting storyline and that's it. It's a marvel movie, it's promising that a sequel will come and that's all I need! It's not X-Men and it will never be, cause it's a different type of movie. On the same topic, it's not spider man, it's not superman, etc. It was an improvement (makes sense) to the poor special effects of 2005, and yes, I liked all the actors! 

Can't wait to see the next one, I hope not in 2025!

Fantastic Four (2015), well let me think here a moment... I'd say the best thing I could possibly say about this movie is:
If you ever wanted to see a movie with fairly done graphics, sort of fair acting, and a story-line that is scripted well enough to suite a He-Man Cartoon then this is it. This film from the graphic work has a ton of money put into the wrong things, the script was very rushed and extremely cheesy. They moved the character opening in way too fast with a ton of skips, then the story sets in so quick it was like watching old G.I. Joe cartoons from the late 80's when you knew the ending would be soon. Simply put this film just didn't have it's stop and starts into play in the story which killed the movie from the moment it started.
The acting was fairly good for what script that it had anyone could've done it, though some of the actors just seemed to not do well in front of a full time green screen situation. Honestly I'd say the trailer is the best of the movie, and thankfully the trailer was short. This film was more of a take your money and run summer flick.

Good God did this movie sucked. Don't get me wrong, the first 40-45 minutes isn't bad, but as soon as a title card comes up reading: one later, the movie changes like a flipped coin, and rushes towards a finality without taking any time for character development or growth for the characters. The first part of the film feels like an Amblin film from back in the 80's and 90's but even so the Fantastic Four have had moments of seriousness, but always have been lighthearted and fun. The campiness of the 2005 film and the constant fun gibing between Chris Evans' and Michael Chiklis' Human Torch and the Thing is now gone and replaced by a dour, humorless and gritty reboot that in someway made me miss the Tim Story films. Sure, they weren't spectacular but Dr. Doom and the characters actually looked like their comic book counterparts and they had an actual plot. This... it's almost like the editor, director, or whoever went out for a walk. 

While Tony Kebbell's Dr. Doom is more menacing than Julian McMahon's and the new powers given to him are actually kind of cool, his motivations for his villainy are never really given enough time to manifest and overall the film is a waste of talented young, rising actors' time and the audience as well.

I went into this expecting complete trash due to initial RT ratings. Frankly speaking, it's got a lot of great ideas but has literally the worst editing/pacing I have seen in a long time in a Hollywood budget action film.

I think Marvel's set a precedent of unnecessarily, colorful, nonstop laugh worthy entertainment to the "super hero" genre that now everyone expects and inadvertently wants. Why? Why does everything have to be sandwiched between glib humor and punchlines? Are we really so incapable of being entertained without a laugh? 

Why can't we appreciate a grounded, dark, charmless hard fiction about a bunch of kids who had their lives fucked up?

Ironically what I love about this iteration of Fantastic Four is that the tone of the film is just downright misery. That having cool super powers isn't "fantastic" at all but actually a dreary affair.

That all being said, great ideas don't flourish without the proper execution and F4 just doesn't make a good film. The pacing is all wrong, it's 80% setup, 20% conflict with an abrupt ending. The resolution itself has no build up, none of the characters had time to resonate or interact, cheapening the whole "we're better together" motif. Reed's brilliant master plan to beat Doom was "Make Ben Invisible so he can punch him"? Really? The ending poses a problem too, 4 kids strong arming the US government to give them whatever they want? What? The Franklin kids don't mourn their fathers death, but in fact joke about it when naming the building? What?

F4 felt like a long pilot for a possibly great TV show, one that I would love to watch. Unfortunately it's just not a great film and at the rate people are bashing this movie we're not likely to get any more "episodes".

Absolutely inconsistent, uneven, undeveloped, and completely rushed to its finish without any effort or special effects skill by its studio, this version of Fantastic Four is a horrendous waste of time (for both me and Josh Trank).

We have to use these powers for good!"  I disagree.  If The Human Torch wants to go set the Taliban on fire, let him.  At least that would be entertaining.

While Fantastic Four isn't the worst superhero movie ever made, it will go down as a prime example of confused superhero filmmaking.  There are some interesting ideas in this movie, and somewhere deep down there is a good movie.  The problem however is twofold: studio meddling, and the fact that the movie it's trying to be just isn't a Fantastic Four movie.  The idea of people with powers suffering and being exploited is actually pretty damn intriguing, but it just doesn't fit the tone of who the Fantastic Four are.  They're a family who have grand adventures, and I never felt that with these guys.  They bicker constantly, not like a family, but like people who genuinely hate each other.  They have no adventures really, with the 90% of the movie taking place in one dull location.  If you took away the Fantastic Four brand and went all out with this vision, you could have an intriguing Cronenberg-esque sci-fi trip, something that could go down as a cult hit.  Even with the Fantastic Four name though, if you went all out with this vision you may at least have something kind of interesting, and that's where the second problem comes in: studio meddling.  It's obvious the studio didn't have faith in the director's vision, and while I don't necessarily blame them, their adjustments just make it worse.  They clearly tried to make it a more standard superhero film at the last minute, but the result is just an embarrassingly sloppy climax with cringe-worthy dialogue and ugly CGI.
The biggest shame of this movie is that it could have been good.  Everyone involved from the director to the actors to the studio, they've all produced good products in the past, and they clearly all have a vision for this thing.  The problem is their visions clashed and just didn't fit the property they were working with.  It's not a fun bad movie, it's just a depressingly bad movie.  But hey, at least it's better than Ghost Rider I guess.

New worst Marvel movie I've seen. They changed a ton of things and the cg stuff was pretty awful, especially with the Thing, who looks like some stop-motion photography gone wrong. The plot dealt entirely with them getting their powers, literally the whole movie deals with that bit. Just really, really bad in almost every conceivable way. After seeing the first three attempts at a Fantastic Four movie, going in to its fourth installment, I thought to myself that it couldn't possibly get any worse. Boy, was I wrong. Not only is this the worst Fantastic Four movie, this also might be the worst superhero movie I have ever seen. This film is an absolute embarrassment. With a director like Josh Trank(Chronicle) attached, this film could have been great. There were SEVERAL writers collaborating to make this film. Not one of them stopped and said, "Guys, this movie just isn't working."
Unfortunately, no one did so. THIS WHOLE FILM IS EXPOSITION. The whole movie is a setup for a sequel. Not only that, but the CGI is laughably bad. Fantastic Four had a huge budget, but still managed to create CGI effects in comparison to the original straight-to-DVD film in the 90's. 

    Also, the actors in this film are all considerably talented. But, for some reason, they just couldn't pull it off. Some of the acting in this film is cringe-worthy, especially from Toby Kebbell. Miles Teller is normally great in films like The Spectacular Now or Whiplash. Michael B. Jordan was awesome in Fruitvale Station. Jamie Bell and Kate mara are fantastic actors. Speaking of Jamie Bell, I have no clue what the f**k he was trying to do in this movie. His performance was just not working at all.

   Fantastic Four is a ludicrous film. I would not wish this film on anyone, and I think it's time to stop trying to make Fantastic Four films. I am beginning to think that it is impossible to make a Fantastic Four film. You would be much better off going to see another film such as The Gift.

The problem is one many origin superhero tales have... where to go with it. If this had been a netflix serial a la Daredevil, this would have made a great first couple of episodes. The problem in the cinema format is they need to do more than just introduce you to these characters because we don't get another eight to twenty hours to delve into the issues the movie teases at. That said despite an anti-climatic climax which is even further stunted by painful dialog, the very solid first half of this film gives it more watchable moments than any other 2015 comic book movie.

I'm not sure why this movie was butchered by critics and the casual moviegoer.I enjoyed this film. Why....here is a nice tidy list!

Really poor excuse for not only a superhero movie or action movie but a poor excuse for a movie in general. At certain points it's as if the filmmakers were aware the movie was a disaster so they were seeing just how bad they could make it by the end. The time jump ruins the only sign of life the movie showed. Poorly acted across the board which surprised me given the talent level. Fox just doesn't seem to know what they're doing in relation to Marvel's First Family. Anti-climactic, boring, and just plain bad. Fantastic Four (take two) is the least fun blockbuster in recent memory.

The film sometimes dazzles with a visual flare, and there certainly are some interesting concepts at play, but Fantastic Four suffers from a lazy script that fails to define its characters or explain almost anything that happens. For the 100 minutes, you try to enjoy the characters (and the likeable actors portraying them), you try to suspend believe but this mess of a film continues to let its audience down. Instead of becoming the next great superhero franchise, it settles to stay on a similar level as the past Fantastic Four movies people have come to hate (at least those films made some sense, weren't cluttered with half-assed CGI and had some entertaining humor and action). What an unfortunate misfire is all I have left to say.

This movie was profusely disappointing.  At the very least this film was better then the terrible early 2000's Fantastic 4 movies.   But sadly that's not saying much.   While the Tim Story movies were way too goofy this movie was way too dark.   The cinematography, acting and special effects were all great.   But the characters, story and writing all sucked.   The first act of the movie followed the Ultimate Fantastic 4 comics so well.   But then it all started going wrong when they got their powers.   Thing becomes a secret super soldier (how can someone as big as him remain a secret?!?!) and we never get to see any of it. and they try and make them pawns of the government.   Then the the film makes the exact same mistake the previous films made.   Rather then making Dr Doom ruler of Latveria and the inventor of a suit of power armor that could put Iron Man to shame.  They try and give him powers and make him crazy.    Gone is everything cool about the dictator with ambitions of world conquest that is doctor doom.   Thing at least looked great in this movie (although seeing his rocky butt-cheeks was something I could have done without) unlike the thing from the original movie that looked like an action figure sculpted out butterfinger candy bar poop.   Johnny Storm was fun but barely in the movie.   Reed Richards was passable at best and Kate Mara who is a great actress is the invisible woman.  they never use her even close to her whole potential though.   Im convinced that at one time this was going to be a good movie but when Disney/Marvel heard that a franchise that technically belonged to them was going to make money they couldn't get at they secretly went about sabotaging it either out of spite or to protect their holdings.   skip this one stick to the comics.

First of all, the only job for the filmmakers was to make this movie better than the previous instalments, which shouldn't have been difficult. I mean, Trank maybe had a better ideo to end the movie, but in the end we dont know who to blame, and we have to judge the end result; which is really bad. I guess they were overthinking this one, or maybe not, maye they did just what they came up with and translated it into something called Fantastic Four. The actors did a good job (which I really didn't expect them to do), but there was not a slight bit of chemistry, which the revious movies did a way better job. Focusing more on the struggle of the Thing is also something previous movies tried, and didn't work out. Trying to make Van Doom more than just a man with a mask and gadgets is cool, I liked it, but you can't call that persona Van Doom (just call him metal gear man with head exploding powers ore something). What really hurts in this movie are the painfully obvious reshoots. The worst part is, they dont even make this movie better, they just unnecessarily steal playtime. The climax of the movie took like 17 minutes. Seriously? C'mon, if you struggle to show the audience everything you want, then make this a 2 1/2h movie (even though I highly doubt that would have helped this movie). I think they could make it better (and by THEY I do mean FOX), but I dont really know how to get people to pay for a Fantastic Four movie anymore, and I think this franchise is buried for the next 10 to 15 years. I hope the F4 come back, and we can do them justice (sometime). It was disappointing, and it was boring, but it didn't make me jump on a bandwagon and hate on it everywhere I go (LIKE IRON MAN 3, fuck that movie).

Time waste.  So another origins story for the troupe, this is an updated story of how the Fantastic Four came to be.  They travel to an alternate universe and become mutated by the elements of this new planet.  I really don't know why this specific group of superheroes is so hard to get right; so far to date, the only time where it has truly excelled is when it was a different title: The Incredibles.  I can't say that I've seen the Roger Corman production, and I don't have a personal connection with the comic books, but I've seen both of the Tim Story movies, and they ranged from okay to mediocre.  I think those two movies catch an unfair amount of flack, but they're still not good films.  With this reboot, they have made something that is far more lacking than either one of the previous movies.  The best thing I can say about the 2005 movie is that it shows that not every superhero movie had to be brooding and dark, and you can have one be more lighthearted; from my understanding this isn't the darkest of superhero stories anyways.  With this reboot, it is back to basics, and there are dark elements all over the place.  Honestly, this really makes me feel bad for critiquing something like Ant-Man for not being perfect, because with this, there really is nothing to recommend about this, and I will happily watch the entirety of the Marvel Cinematic Universe before I will ever pick this up again.  So where to begin with everything that is wrong with this.  For one thing, there are no surprises to be had here.  It's another origins story for a group that everybody is already well aware of; nobody wants to see another Spider-Man origins, Superman origins or Batman origins, and nobody wants to see this, either.  It's just like a bad cover song at karaoke of a song that wasn't all that great to begin with, and you just want the drunken man to get off the stage.  I am not exaggerating when I say that it takes a full 45 minutes before something new happens.  I have heard differing stories on how much this was studio intervention and how much was director Josh Trank, and it doesn't really matter, because everybody is to blame and we all lose.  These aren't terrible actors; I've seen Miles Teller knock it out of the park in Whiplash, Michael B. Jordan bring it in Fruitvale Station, and Toby Kebbell deliver a gut punch in Dead Man's Shoes.  That said, I feel that every single person here is miscast, and nobody shares any chemistry with one another, they are just going through the motions and reading the lines on the page.  The dialogue is as clunky and boring as the rock planet that they go to, which brings me to the next point: the effects look cheap.  I don't know if somebody pocketed the majority of the $120 million budget, but the special effects look like they could have been rendered another few times over, and to have not one but two of your most climactic scenes take place on a barren rock planet is not an exciting choice to make for your adventure movie.  The villain motivation is weak and questionable, and the more I think about this, the less I like it, and I don't have anything good to say about this overly dull action film, which, in itself, is saying something.

Fantastic Four is thuddingly awful, completely unfun, stupid, and not even bad enough to be funny -- it's a painful eyesore that looks like it was made with the budget of an indie film by idiots who don't know how to use green-screen effectively.

It's not hard to make a Fantastic 4 movie that's more entertaining than the previous two that came before this one. The dark tone is welcome to the franchise and there are some flashes of greatness such as when Reed first encounters the Thing post-incident and the very last few seconds, and although I don't like the general youth of the actors, the talent involved is actually pretty solid. Fantastic Four is the new attempt to making a good Fantastic Four movie.Needless to say it is another very much failed attempt to do so.
Now this movie actually started fine.Reed seemed interesting enough and Miles Teller is actually a very good actor and he was delivering it.Some things don't work even in the beginning of course,but overall it was fine and nothing too terrible about it.
Then the movie tries to be smart and dark which just turns out as laughable and boring.This movie takes itself way to seriously and it really should not have.Unfortunately even the Special Effects very really bad,and I was watching it and asking myself how could a 2015 Superhero movie look so bad.Nothing looked real or believable here.Especially Doom,whose design was really bad and his face looked like so terrible that at a point it just makes you laugh at it.
The overall acting is fine,there's nothing too terrible about it.The dialogue wasn't as terrible either,not most of the time at least because there are some lines that are really bad too.Also the running time is not long at all,but by the end the movie just feels like it's dragging on and that is not a good thing at all.
The final battle though sealed it for me,there I was like,that's it,this movie sucks.It tries to be this dark and giant battle and you're supposed to feel for the main characters and feel the weight of this supposedly enormous battle but it just comes out as the worst part of the movie with super bad looking effects that make it look like something that came out of a very bad looking video game that no one cares,loves or buys it.

Josh Trank's "Fantastic Four" is the latest attempt to earn 20th Century Fox some super hero cred outside of the X-Men franchise, but once again, all hopes were dashed come opening weekend. No one knows what caused this disaster of a film, but a great cast of talented actors couldn't get it right, nor a director with enough creativity to build his own superhero movie (in the form of "Chronicle," which was far better than this) was enough to make this franchise into a success. It was dark, gloomy, ultra-scientific with none of the fun and excitement that makes the MCU films SO successful. In short, let's hope Fox cuts their losses and decide not to attempt a sequel- really, who wants it?

We all know the story: Mr Fantastic, The Invisible Woman, The Human Torch and The Thing take on Victor Von Doom, a villain once their own, and infected with the same energy source they have all been affected by, wants to eradicate Earth and only the four can stop him. And in 2015, the Fantastic Four have contracted another chance on the big screen, but this version is a very different interpretation of Marvel√¢??s main superhero family to the Tim Story versions of a decade ago. There has been much hype about this reboot that looked intriguing when the trailer came out, but as it has now been released, it seemingly should have followed the recipe for superhero films Marvel Studios have perfected. Unfortunately, this new Fantastic Four capitulates under the numerous mistakes it conceives, much to our surprise, for it has all the elements to be fantastic.
 
Seeing as this version starts off with all the characters separately, they have to bond lots to become tightknit, and unfortunately they never really feel like a group once. We can√¢??t ever understand their close bond as friends, siblings, lovers or enemies because we don√¢??t get to see them bond, and this is a major problem because to us the characters don√¢??t mesh as a unit, and so we see an empty group of heroes who still seem by the end strangers. The characters are thoroughly underused, for only when they talk scientifically do we feel like the film is getting somewhere, but when they try to make small talk for the purpose of character building and relationship bonding, they fail miserably because this script does not make time for it, in fact it fails to make time for any of the moments that make the recent crop of superhero films as successful as they are. Each character cannot be distinguished from one another until their powers ever so poorly cling onto them. They are all brainy scientists with poor upbringings, yet their ambition to do great makes them unique people who struggle to get along with other humans, therefore, all five characters are effectively carbon copies of each other, minus the radical beliefs. So, how can we embrace the characters if the only diversity comes with the usurping of their powers? And to make matters worse, the powers aren√¢??t made to look entertaining at all, and like all its problems, we don√¢??t see much of it, and when we do, the bits chosen don√¢??t tickle our fancy.
 
Miles Teller is our protagonist Reed Richards AKA Mr Fantastic, a genius with the ability to stretch like rubber. Teller falls into his character better than Ioan Gruffudd ever did, but the thinness of his character means shallowness to a lot of things because he is our protagonist. Kate Mara√¢??s Susan Storm is far worse than Jessica Alba√¢??s creation; all we feel is her cold exterior we can never penetrate. We can√¢??t even begin to hope for a romance between her and Richards because her lacklustre performance prevents the idea from even popping into our heads. Michael B. Jordan, despite being black is the sister of Susan, who is white, making her his adopted sister, and to be honest to confuse their lineage doesn√¢??t add complexity to anything, it merely makes them feel more like strangers. Because his father is the group√¢??s guide, Jordan√¢??s Johnny Storm has depth to his character, unlike his partners, but he isn√¢??t even the second or third protagonist! Ben Grimm is the most neglected of the lot, lacking brains and brawn, and screen time! We don√¢??t even get to see Jamie Bell that much, but all of a sudden after a mishap is made out of rock, and becomes the heart of the group. This confusion isn√¢??t helped by The Thing√¢??s poor appearance that blocks emotion. And Victor Von Doom, the villain with a hell-bent vision that Earth needs to be destroyed because humans have driven it to deterioration is a weak enemy. Every feeling of his is under-emphasised, from his hatred of other humans, humanity√¢??s treatment of Earth and his love for Susan; therefore he becomes quite a one-dimensional character with the inability to express his emotions. Toby Kebbell does what he can with Victor, but in the end what we have is an undercooked villain with radical beliefs that have come out of nowhere due to his embittered personality that has dealt with constant rejection.
 
The development of the story is interesting at the start, playing upon the inter-dimensional travel ploy that is a big feature for the film, and one we can potentially understand in our technology-heavy society. When teleportation is achieved, the planet they teleport to, named Zero, is the most interesting this film can hope for. It is fascinating that the protagonists go there and actually investigate their surroundings, something which the 2005 Fantastic Four embarrassingly attempts to do, and even though the most we know about this planet is its man-made name and green lava-like substance, there isn√¢??t much to remember about it, and that is Fantastic Four√¢??s major problem. It suffers from the inability to delve into the interesting details of its story, which although there are plenty, it doesn√¢??t realise which ones are which and suffers. To see a film unable to control its own story, and provide life into memorable superheroes is sad viewing, because Fantastic Four is a mess that has potential, but the filmmakers here haven√¢??t understood what constitutes into making a story develop and flow.
 
Fantastic Four cannot flow properly therefore the narrative is unbalanced throughout. The opening is given plenty of time to develop, but the shortness of the running time makes the film miss large sections, which feels like it jumps ahead from scene to scene, and the scenes that are chosen lack importance or clarity. Upon the return of Victor 80 minutes in, the film is suddenly at a climax, allowing the audience to turn to one another and give a stare of √¢??did I fall asleep or is that it?√¢?? because the bridging scenes are absent, making this film feel rushed because it fails to dedicate its time equally around the film. About half-way in, the induction of a montage that tries to forward the story in terms of character bonding and the building of the teleportation device shows just how clearly the filmmakers didn√¢??t know what they were doing. If the montage were converted into actual scenes, all of the criticism I√¢??ve levelled at the film would be deemed obsolete, because Fantastic Four would then become layered, both in terms of the characters and story.
 
For some reason, the film maintains an obscure tone that suits the film on occasions but cannot be understood why it is so dark. To allow for the characters to bond and for us to create a connection to the film, there has to be far more of a lighter quality to the proceedings, maybe not as much as Chris Evans brought as The Human Torch, but definitely some kind of comic relief that could take the seriousness down a notch or two. I actually don√¢??t understand why there needs to be a dark tone because the characters are all young, ambitious and on the verge of ground-breaking discovery, and not once is there the threat of evil until the last 10 minutes, so as you can see the imbalance is rife. Reg E. Cathey√¢??s addition as Dr Franklin Storm, parent of Johnny and Sue, whom you may know as the guy who makes tasty-ass ribs in House of Cards, is the guy that brings this gloomy fa√É¬ßade over the film, despite being a strong character who you can actually feel is acting. His addition gives the characters an anchor they can rebel against and return to, but most importantly his level-headedness stops the characters from relaxing before and after they gain their abilities. Without Franklin as a guide to the group, the gloominess would not have potentially been achieved, and the characters would have had to guide themselves, making for a more reckless film with the capacity to amaze.
 
The short running time means the ending is so lacklustre and insanely quick, it will definitely leave you underwhelmed by the whole experience that didn√¢??t develop, intrigue or satisfy such an interesting beginning. The location of the climax is boring, the fighting is tedious and the visuals are so monotonous it would not even take a film buff to notice it. Director Josh Trank has said the final package wasn√¢??t his version because 20th Century Fox made cuts to the script without his supervision, and so with his dissatisfaction sky-high, it doesn√¢??t change a thing because Fantastic Four was a mess nonetheless. These superheroes need to be left in their comic books fighting evil without critics embarrassing them for a fourth time!
 
The Verdict:
 
Fantastic Four has glimmers of the great superhero film it could have become, but in the end, this reboot has torn apart the characters√¢?? dignity and the world√¢??s love for this family of heroes.
 
√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??√¢??        2/10

I went into the cinema ready to make up my own mind. I was so disappointed when I heard that the film was a let-down. Well, it completely bombed basically. I loved the trailer. I was enthralled unbeknownst to me that the film advertised was in fact a FF reboot.

And that's what still sells it to me now despite all the flack it's getting. This is a reboot. It's a stand-alone film with inspiration from famous comics and the characters within them. I guess it's easy for me to say as I don't have any attachment to the comics or their beloved characters.

I adore the fresh, grounded approach to known stories, in this case the younger characters are more modern and seem to deal with 21st century issues. The superpowers are explained by science much like other superhero films but in a way that seems like it could quite possibly happen in the news today. It sounds silly to say that it doesn't feel far-fetched by the atmosphere that engaged me leading me into a reality that made it seem possible.

Using a body horror angle to introduce the characters' powers was a breath of fresh, cool air. To show these characters as real people would behave was something new that I felt needed to be done to refresh the superhero genre. Some effects seemed a little gimmicky but only after a friend pointed it out to me. I think they could've actually taken the whole story in this direction (as the horror was only hinted at and quickly brushed aside) however they chose to skip ahead and get to the action.

Not a lot of people enjoyed the pace of the film, they complained about the lack of action and the slow-burning build that seemed to drag. I however, loved the detail that went into the set-up for these characters as I'm not easily engaged by constant action. And as a reboot, it seemed important and such a good opportunity to flesh out a completely new origin. I think people wanted to see more of the superheroes and didn't care much for the people behind them. Despite this, the characters personalities' were quite one-dimensional which explains why the first 2 acts fell short for a lot of people.

This leads to an issue with the third act, which for the length of the film, seems like an after-thought. In my mind, they could've gone two ways. First, they could've given more running time to allow for a better built-up, fleshed out and authentic action sequence that threaded better into the story rather than choosing a dark and brooding character to suddenly just go, 'you know what? Fuck Earth.' Or, they should've made the final act about what their new bodies would mean for their place in society i.e. make the antagonist the military/government that tries to take their freedom (crudely described; apologies). THEN we could introduce Doctor Doom in the sequel. Get where I'm going?

But alas, this was not the case and therefore this was far from a perfect film. However, I still enjoyed it as a whole based on the sum of it's good parts.

Fantastic 4 with all the bad press and criticism it received I expected to see possibly  the worst movie ever. In fact i got quite the opposite. I wonder how much of this can be attributed to the casting of Michael B. Jordan as the human torch. Interesting enough he was one of the better things about the film. To say it is the worst movie ever made is ridiculous. Worse than Gigli, Glitter, Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun Li, Dragon Ball Z, Battlefield Earth or any Uwe Boll film? The answer is unequivocally no. 

F4 starts off really well. First half of the film is scripted intelligently and well paced. It was actually intriguing and had me thoroughly engaged. The 1st half of the film truly felt complete. It's the other half that was a total mess and where it all falls apart. That was also the major problem the film can be dissected by its two acts and quite apparent missing a middle act. Rumors of studio meddling points to this disjointed mess of movie that  could have been otherwise a good picture. Cutting the budget, taking away three major action sequences and took over final cut of the film. Josh Trank is a talented director anyone who has seen Chronicle would know this to be true. I wish he would have been allowed t o make the movie he wanted. I guess we will never see it and for now we have to live with the film that exists now.

Como era de esperarse, la pel√≠cula se estren√≥ y lamentablemente su recepci√≥n en la cr√≠tica y en la taquilla fue un desastre. Toda la pol√©mica alrededor del film se traslad√≥ a la audiencia de una forma incre√≠blemente negativa. Ir√© un poco m√°s lejos y dir√© que se exager√≥ un poco, incluso. La explicaci√≥n de mi opini√≥n la dar√© ahora en la cr√≠tica.

El film inicia mostr√°ndonos el nacimiento de la amistad entre Reed Richards (Teller) y Ben Grimm (Bell) cuando eran ni√±os. Ambos pasan a√±os desarrollando el viaje interdimensional hasta que llegan a la secundaria y son reclutados por el Doctor Franklin Storm (Cathey) y su hija Sue (Mara). "Lo que cuenta es la intenci√≥n", dice el dicho y la intenci√≥n de Trank es muy buena al llevar a la familia de superh√©roes a sus ra√≠ces: la ciencia ficci√≥n. This film was very poor from the beginning. It was trying so hard to get the younger crowd more interested in seeing the film by hiring young and popular actors. The plot had holes as well, I mean it just pulled in a nerdy kid who has little experience working in a professional filed, to build  giant teleprter. Then they pretend they need him after he finishes the job, succeeds in getting to the new planet, and then leaves his friends to escape the governments control. All his research was probably closely documented, not to mention his 3 partners who helped in the teleporter's success and are there to help build it! Then the actors were so young that I really hated the affliction given when delivering lines. Like the world is about to end, everyone you love is going to die, and your partner Victor is the cause; and you're telling me your going to SPEAK NOT YELL "Victor don't." Really? I don't feel like you could even act calm in that type of situation. Then the line "I'm a adult, dad!"  This line was delivered very oddly.I would expect either a low and cool delivery or a very loud angry, almost teen way, of delivery. Instead the delivery was a combination of both like the actor could not make up his mind on how to deliver the line. Both the characters Ben and Johnny felt very neglected in the movie as well. The enemy was too over powered and could not have been beat. The fantastic 4 suddenly stop breathing oxygen for the boss fight. Not enough energy after the death of Johnny and  Sue's dad's death. I mean he helped all but Ben through the movie and I feel like a lot of anger and energy would have been released at such a time.  (Johnny did at least show a bit of anger seconds after his father was struck). Reed was just awful. Never really liked the character any way, but with the poor delivery of lines and the character being portrayed in a very fake and, at times, as the actor himself way I just could not believe that reeve was a three dimensional person like we all are. I mean where was the inner thoughts and depth. Sue did have depth but she also got neglected in some parts and just could not carry the other actors with her.The older actors in this move were well seasoned and just very unfortunate enough to be in this film. At times I felt that the actors forced the young actors to actually feel and be in the scenes.The ending sucked not only because of the plot holes and overpowered villain, but because the young actors had to actually carry a scene out by themselves. I admit that being on set with a green screen, no props, and looking up at a, probably, really nice coworker while tying to be in character is hard, but its your job! Like you get paid to act, so do it right! Use your imagination and touch on feelings. Don't be afraid to show your emotions. There was just too much "trying to be cool" going on. The fact that your still young in the movie means you should be showing even more emotion. You haven't had the years to learn how to completely control your emotions and keep cool. In fact I don't think a single person could be in such control at the end of the world. Where is the director! You couldn't tell the actors this?!? Did you not care that they totally forgot how to act? Did you even try to re-film the acting? The only thing that got this in theaters was the fact it marvel, has action, and the graphics were professional. Besides that it sucked.

I am aware of what happened behind the scenes. I'm even aware of how Trank bailed at the last moment and I am definitely aware that the last 20 minutes of the movie needed more work. But you'd be foolish to disagree that this movie had all the makings of a Marvel Studios Movie (The Thor Kind, not the other movies which have levity involved where all the science is just simply deemed as "Alien" to soothe everyone) and that they hired the right talent for it which could've seriously taken it all the way.

OK, so is it a darker movie with awkward jokes and convenient science, rather than a self aware movie, like Guardians of the Galaxy, which gets to joke around about standing in circles? Sure. But its a good movie. Bear in mind, I'm not implying that its the best that Fox Studios has to offer but its still better than all the crap I have suffered through this year that made more money. I understand how you'd think that this thought has no basis of merit but I disagree. Hear me out. Lets assume you enjoyed a movie that everyone else hated on but you kept your silence as you are aware that every movie is subjective, but then suddenly, using the mass consensus as a weapon, everyone dog piles on a movie that you didn't really mind, and you end up getting a bit underwhelmed with the overall response as you liked a movie that everyone else didn't enjoy. And It all just seems like an immature joke that you had a great time with but the others around you didn't really understand or may be even unimpressed by it, which leaves you poking everyone with your elbow saying "huh, huh?"

Well I'm stuck in that category. I am one of those 3 guys that liked that bomb of a bollywood movie called Gunday and faced a similar heat when everyone criticized it based on what they heard rather than what the movie made you experience (despite the flaws), and I'd like to keep F4 on the same platform - As an underrated and severely hated on movie that hopefully, in the future, be considered as, at best, an average movie that we are strong armed to concede with as an "OK movie that history remembered, when it could've easily be forgotten"

P.S.  I think they set themselves up for a sequel and I'd pay my money to watch it.

The plot was non-existent since you had to wait 90 minutes to get to what the plot should have been: Dr. Doom vs. Fantastic Four and it only lasted 5 minutes. Then add in the awful casting. At least in the previous Fantastic Four films it was more believable that Mr. Fantastic would be one of the smartest people in the world. In this film, they have them be college students which is the most unrealistic thing possible....even in a Sci-Fi action movie.

Fantastic Four is a very dark movie. I mean, really dark. I mean dark, as in, somebody please flip some lights on. That's not a joke; every scene in this movie is so under-lit that you feel like your wearing sunglasses indoors. Every outdoor scene feel you're attending a vampire funeral. It is a funerary tone is unfortunately appropriate because this is a joyless, dead serious movie that rings all of the energy out of something that should be bouncy and fun.

This is the fourth failed movie rendition of this property and the fourth time that Hollywood has shown that it doesn't have a clue how to do it right. Roger Corman's legendary 1994 action-comedy was so infamous that it never got released. The 2005 Fantastic Four movie and its sequel Rise of the Silver Surfer, were colorful but featherbrained and forgettable. Yet, they were modern masterpieces compared to director Josh Trank's current modernization, a movie so joyless that makes the last hour of Revenge of the Sith feel like Christmas morning.

At the beginning of the new Fantastic Four - or as the poster calls it, 'Fant-4-stic' - we meet 10 year-old Reed Richards (Owen Judge) who is working on a matter transfer machine.  He becomes friends with young Ben Grimm (Evan Hannemann) whose family owns a junkyard and has the parts that Reed needs. They become friends and grow up working together on the project, but years later at their high school science fair, their teacher (Dan Castelanetta) dismisses their amazing discovery as "a magic show."

The government is more interested in their discovery and gives them access to work on it - along with Sue Storm (Kate Mara) and Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), and a broody drop-out named Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell) who is said to be from Latvaria, but has an accent that is true-blue America. The team is given access to The Least Secure Government Research Facility on the Face of the Earth. Seriously, they can go anywhere, do anything, and send out photos of themselves to their buddies without any restrictions what-so-ever.

The first test of the matter-transfer machine with a chimp is successful, but Reed (played as an adult by Miles Teller) thinks that he and his team would be perfect for the first human test. The project overseer (Tim Blake Nelson) wants to bring in astronauts, but Reed is undaunted and wants to try it out himself. After hours, he gathers the team for an unauthorized test, but things go wrong and they, of course, find themselves with magical powers. Reed can stretch. Johnny becomes a human torch. Ben turns into a walking, talking chunk of rocks. And, for no reason at all, Sue gets the power to turn invisible, which is a head-scratcher because she didn't go on the mission at all - she was at the lab computer, so okay.

The introduction of these elements make up the movie's first hour. We are laboriously introduced to every single character. Then after the accident, we are laboriously introduced to all of their superpowers. By the time the introductions are over, we have time for a ten minute action scene before the movie abruptly ends. The worse section of the movie are the discovery of the powers. What should be a moment of joy and discovery is a long, sad series of 'what-have-you-done-to-me' scenes that have the same tone as if someone's dog just died.

The idea here should yield a movie that is as joyful and fun as last year's Guardians of the Galaxy. Quite the opposite. This is a grim, mean-spirited and broody movie. Instead of a fantasy, we get the approximation of how these events might play out in real life. That's exactly the wrong approach. The characters spend much of the time getting to know each other that you feel like you're watching the pilot to a TV series.

The comic books, as I remember them, were colorful and fun. The team felt like a cohesive family unit whose chief quirk is that their differing personalities meant that they were always playfully squabbling with one another - like a family. Here they seem to have been pulled together from central casting. The actors do what they can, but never at any time are they required to give us any sense of joy or wonderment. What was the thinking here? Why make a summer action movie this gloomy and oppressive? Why spend 90% of the movie on introductions? Why set the entire movie in a lab? Why give it such a mean-spirited tone? Fans of the movie won't recognize the characters.  Non-fans will be repelled by the movie's repellant atmosphere.  Who was this movie made for?

NOTE: There are no credit cookies, midway or at the end.  Which is okay, because the less time spent with this mess, the better.

In an era where superhero movies are the biggest box office attractions and dominate the summer movie season, its alarming to find a movie so dull, boring, and soul-less as Fantastic 4, or as 20th Century Fox has decided to spell it for some reason, Fant4stic. The movies first and second acts are relatively unoffensive. While not exactly exciting or even fun to watch, it would have been just average enough to make this movie OK. I started to get worried when, 45 minutes into the movie, it seemed that nothing relevant  had happened in the plot yet. The heroes still hadn't gotten their powers, there had been no big action set-pieces we come to expect at this point, and none of the characters had developed in a way to make me feel any emotional connection towards them. Then the film begins to fall apart at a baffling pace, as the words "ONE YEAR LATER" appear on the screen right in the middle of the second act. What follows is a few poorly edited, short and boring action sequences that look like they were ripped directly out of a sci-fi channel original movie. Then the bad guy shows up and decides to destroy the world for absolutely no reason at all, the boring heroes fight him in one of the worst third acts I've ever seen in a movie, and then it just ends with some of the most painful to listen to dialogue I've ever heard in a movie my entire life. If you like superhero movies, or even movies in general, don't watch this film for any reason.

I was looking forward to this when I first saw the trailer.  Then I heard about the problems during production and issues with the director. Then the reviews came out. I decided that I would go ahead and see it on the big screen.  
First, it doesn't help that Marvel wasn't in charge.  It's not as good a film as what's been produced for the MCU but that's ok.  Marvel has done a wonderful job and set the bar high.  I'm sure that hurt the reaction here some. I enjoyed the story. It was good enough for a reboot. I thought the acting was fine. SFX was good as well. I liked how the relationship between Reed & Ben was fleshed out.  It did seem that 3/4 of the film was devoted to the origin.  That seems like a lot more than the other superhero films that deal with origins.  I suspect that hurt reviews too. After the 4 find themselves capable of using their powers, it seems like the film has less superhero action than other films and the climatic battle is rather straight forward and relatively short. I'd watch another film with these characters. I hope I get too but I understand I'm definitely in the minority in my view of this one.

After the overall O.K. previous Fan 4 films, all Trank and the team at 20th Century Fox needed to do was to make a worthwhile film, about a team of friends who had to adjust to life with their new-found Superpowers.

That was the one thing Fox absolutely couldn't do. 

The First mistake in this film is the director. Yes, Trank was a good choice at first, but the more reports came in of Trank's behaviour on set, and after Kate Mara (Susan Storm/The Invisible Woman) was told not to read the comics, and Trank was allegedly turning up to set drunk, and shutting himself off from society, the movie was immediatley doomed.

The Second thing they screwed up with the film was the characters. None of these characters projected the original wit and fun of the comic book heroes. Even though the actors (Mostly Teller as Reed Richards, Mara as Sue Storm, Bell as Ben Grimm and B. Jordan as Johnny Storm though) tried to save the film, no-one could really help the fact that the script was witless, and the characters were pointless. The main disappointment in this aspect of the film however is the plain lazyness and downright insulting way the villian - Viktor Von Doom/Doctor Doom was written. Instead of being an evil egomaniac bent on revenge towards his former friends, he becomes a stupid, video game playing nerd, who has a slight crush on Sue, and is angry cause he got... um... burnt a bit? 

The Last and most important part of this film that they screwed up, was the pacing. I timed the film, and 45 minutes into the film, and it's an hour and a half long film, 45 minutes in, they return from Planet Zero, with their powers. Then the credits are about 7 minutes long, so you minus 7 from around 45 minutes, brings you to around 38 minutes. They have their powers in this film for 38 minutes, minus the time it takes them to do the most expositioney piece of writing of all time to explain their power which is about 5 minutes, so that brings us to 33 minutes of them having their powers. And to make matters worse Doctor Doom returns as the villian for the final fight, 15 minutes before the film ends. And 5 of those minutes, is the final fight, Doctor Doom is expositioned for 10 minutes, and in those minutes: He kills about 30 people by exploding their heads, with... his mind? I guess. Reed and Ben talk. Johnny accidentally attacks Sue. Doctor Doom kills Sue and Johnny's father. The World starts to get sucked up into a black hole. 
Hang on while we're on the subject of the final fight and that god damn wormhole piece of crap, lets focus souley on that. So Doctor Doom was trapped on Planet Zero for a year now, and somehow found a hoodie cloak (no seriously where'd he get that?) and when he comes back, hes already figured out how to blow up people's heads or suck the life out of them or something, and create a freaking Black Hole? Yeah sure, it looked cool. But it was a piece of shit. I mean come on, Doom created a freaking Black Hole with his mind, and then, um, what was his plan after that? What was he supposed to try and do? What was his goal in life? WHY DID DOCTOR DOOM EXIST!!!

If this was a film about a group of kids getting superpowers, and trying to learn how to deal with them, and then one (Viktor) goes rogue and they team up to stop him. It would've been great, it may have even been one of the best superhero films of all time. It had potential, but FANT4STIC is a clear defintion that Superhero films can still suck balls
