The Fantastic Four returns to theaters in this dark and gritty reboot and the result in anything but fantastic, more in the ways of pathetic and horrendous. The Fantastic Four has had a troubled history on screen. Roger Corman produced in a film in 1994 which was never released into theaters, with the characters finding their first official on screen adventure in 2005's Fantastic Four, directed by Tim Story. Despite mixed reviews, the film was still a success at the box office and warranted a sequel entitled Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer, released in 2007. While that film received mixed reviews, slightly better than the 2005 film, it wasn't considered a box office success, causing Twentieth Century Fox to abort a third film and reboot the franchise all together. This new version arrives eight years after Rise of the Silver Surfer and ten years after the first, and the result is absolutely terrible.

This film has been known for its behind the scenes production problems, which have been highly talked about and appeared on the internet. Director Josh Trank and the studio, Fox, had a difficult relationship, while even Trank was known for being difficult to work with and erratic on set, causing various problems, including damages worth around $100,000 involving a house rented out to him.

The film focuses on Reed Richards, a high school student, who is working on a teleportation device, with help from his friend Ben Grimm. Their work attracts the attention of Professor Franklin Storm, director of the Baxter Foundation, which is funded by the government. Storm recruits Reed, who joins his adopted daughter Susan Storm to help complete a Quantum Gate, with aid from Johnny Storm, Franklin's biological son and Victor Von Doom, the creator of the Gate. After successfully testing the Gate by sending a monkey to an alternate dimension, the government decides to coordinate with Nasa by sending their own people through the Gate, forcing Reed, Johnny, Victor and a reluctant Ben to decide to carry out their own expedition. Arriving to the dimension, the group is suddenly threatened and attempts to escape, leaving Victor behind after he supposedly dies. Upon returning, the three survivors, as well as Susan, suddenly develop strange powers, prompting the government to test them. This is where the whole film goes down hill.

The film doesn't really have any real structure, who no exact pacing, while it appears like a badly put-together jigsaw puzzle with all the wrong pieces and none of the right pieces. The result is a film with no real pacing. Almost every scene seems rushed, while there is no real resolution.

The cast, sadly, doesn't do well in this film, which is a shame, since they are good actors. Miles Teller doesn't seem fit for the role of Reed and doesn't seem like a scientist. In much of the film, while he attempts to put forth scientific equations and tests, he at times feels more like an outcast. After the team develops their powers, Reed disappears, going into hiding, which doesn't really support the film or have any real merit to the plot. It just feels like it's thrown in there. Going along with Teller, Trank fought for him to be in the role, but after casting and before production, there's news that Trank and Teller developed a bad relationship, which could have effected the character and Teller's performance. Kate Mara, as Susan, is terrible, which is sad, since I have found her best performance to be in House of Cards. There is news that Fox insisted on her casting and that Trank treated her coldly as a result, possibly resulting in what we have screen. That there is really disappointing, since Mara probably could have given much more to the role and the film. Jamie Bell isn't convincing as Ben Grimm, though he handles the performance of the Thing perfectly. The same goes with Michael B. Jordan who isn't convincing as Johnny Storm and isn't given much to do with. Both Jordan and Bell are fine actors and like with Teller and Mara, it's a shame to see them not have much to do. Toby Kebbell isn't menacing or convincing as Victor Von Doom, while he doesn't prove to be a scientific genius, more like an anti-social outsider, which greatly ruins and effects the character. Tim Blake Nelson chews the scenery as government stooge Dr. Allen and Reg E. Cathey isn't interesting as mentor Franklin Storm.

A big problem with this film is the pacing. Like I said before, the film feels like a badly put-together jigsaw puzzle. There's no real structure, while it seems that the film skips the second act and goes straight to the third act, which instantly makes no sense to the viewer and to the film's story. After the team gains their powers and Reed goes into hiding, the film instantly cuts to a year later, which effects the film. Johnny, Susan and Ben have learned how to handle and use their powers, though we never see them learning how to use them. I would have liked to see them training to learn their powers, since this would have made for sense as to how later in the film they know how to control them. In Iron Man and Batman Begins, you had an origin as to Tony Stark creating the Iron Man uniform and Bruce Wayne developing the Bat-Suit, here though there is no real origin. It seems forced. Another major problem is that the team never has a real threat to face. There are reports that before production began Fox cut three key action scenes from the film, which probably one of the main reasons as to why after gaining their powers, developing them and using them, they don't face a real threat. In Iron Man, you have Tony facing off against his terrorist captors in Gulmira after he masters the Iron Man suit. In Batman Begins, Bruce takes down Carmine Falcone and starts to slowly liberate Gotham City. Here, no real threat.

Which also brings us to Dr. Doom. In the comics, Dr. Doom is a well-known villain and one of the chief adversaries of the Fantastic Four. Here, he doesn't seem like a real villain. After escaping the dimension and leaving Victor behind, since they believe him to be dead, I kept wondering where the villain was, how was he plotting his return. When Nelson's character sends a small group back to the dimension after Reed fixes the Gate, they find Doom and the film is almost over, a major problem I also had with Hugh Laurie's so-called villainous character in Tomorrowland. Here, sadly, Doom isn't a real threat, he's underused. Even Tim Blake Nelson isn't a real threat, he's more like a scenery chewing villain. Sure he wants to use the Fantastic Four as government weapons and take over the alternate dimension, but still there's no real motivation. The same with Dr. Doom, which is a problem. In The Dark Knight, the Joker's motivation is clear: he wants to cause chaos, destroy Gotham and bend Batman to his will. Even if Skyfall, Javier Bardem's Silva wants to kill M and gain revenge. Here, Doom has no real motivation. Doom isn't even a danger to the team.

The team also doesn't seem like a real team. They don't seem like the Fantastic Four. All of a sudden, after Doom's appearance and threat, do they manage to work together and trust each other. Up until than, not so much. Once again, it would have seemed better for the team to get know each other, their powers and how to work together. Here, it seems forced.

While the special effects in the film are fine, especially with the Thing, Reed, Johnny and Susan, the ones for Doom are not. It seems that toward the end, the studio came to the point where they felt they developed good effects for the other characters, but didn't need to for Doom. Here it's a shame. Doom doesn't look interesting. He seems more like a crash-test dummy thrown into acid, more like a joke.

The other problem with the film is that it is also too dark. This is a problem, since every comic book movie doesn't need to be dark, gritty and grounded. While it worked with Christopher Nolan's Batman trilogy and even several films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, it didn't really work with the Spider-Man reboot, The Amazing Spider-Man and The Amazing Spider-Man 2. It's almost as if some filmmakers have started to think that if Nolan could darken Batman and ground him and make him gritty, other comic book films can do the same. Not so much. The gritty and bleak feel ruins Fantastic Four. It would have worked better if this film was lighter and more colorful, more like Sam Raimi's Spider-Man.

Marco Beltrami and Philip Glass try their best with the score, but seem to be underused at times, which is also a shame, considering that they are great composers.

The end result is a film that seems to be made by committee, by a bunch of board members sitting in a room and throwing out ideas. While we can blame Fox for interfering with the director, we should also probably blame Trank. While he claims that his version would have been better had Fox not interfered, the big question is: How would had it been better? 

What Fox needs to do is give this property back to Marvel, who will probably make a way better film, or else choose a director that they can trust and work well on this kind of film. The film isn't fantastic, it's pathetic. Terrible. Horrendous.

The only good thing is that it's 100 minutes long and when the credits appear, you are pleased that it's over, despite wasting 100 minutes of your life on a real clunker. This one is a real mess and will probably stand as the worst comic book film, worst than Batman and Robin, while it also makes 2005's Fantastic Four appears much better and a lot like art. Which isn't saying much honestly. Pass on this film and see a better comic book film.

True it could be better, but its still a good origin story. A part of me wants to see what happens next. Marvel is going be one of the best studios to transform their comics into films, that is actually perfected well. Their recent slew of movies based on their properties has been well received amongst both critics and audiences alike. Until now. With the release of "Fantastic Four", the studio has stumbled upon a major dud, and might set the company back for a little while. The film itself is bad film, but it is definitely not the worst movie Marvel has released. There is potential here, we're just not seeing it. "Fantastic Four" is a perfect example of letting a studio take over the production, and supplying the needs and wants of the fans. And ultimately, it just comes out as one big mess.

The plot involves four young minds working on a way to teleport towards another dimension. Unfortunately, a freak accident causes the quartet to gain supernatural powers. These include Reed Richards (Miles Teller) developing elasticity throughout his entire body. Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan) setting his entire body on fire. Sue Storm (Kate Mara) can turn invisible and create forcefields. And Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell) whose whole body has been transformed into a piece of solid rock. Can the four of them work together, or will their personal issues get in the way?

Oh, boy. "Fantastic Four" is a bad movie. To begin with, the special effects look nice, but it feels like everything is fake, especially with Bell's Thing; whenever the character is on screen, all the audience sees is just a computer generated image walking around. It defeats the illusion of what we're seeing isn't always there. The sets, again, look nice, but everything is done in the computer, it makes the audience wonder why the filmmakers didn't bother with building actual sets that looked real enough to make the audience think it is believable. It just feels cheap and unnecessary. The editing is another big issue as everything (except for the first third), feels absolutely rushed, and makes the whole production feel predictable.

But the biggest issue that the movie has going for it is the writing. There are various plot threads that feel left out, and could have been explored a bit further. The team gets their powers way too easily; we get the traditional training montage of the team using their powers, and we've seen it done before. Along with the terrible editing, the writing plays a role in this traditional formula by expanding the timeline of events happening in the movie with no regards with what is going on. This happens, and this happens; it's just formulaic.

Now, with that being said, is there anything good about the movie? Well, the cast does a good job in their roles, and their direction by Josh Trank isn't bad. Plus, the orchestrated score does a nice job setting the tone of the film. But other than that, the film just suffers from the aforementioned problems.

In conclusion, "Fantastic Four" could have easily been given another chance, had the production actually spent some time in the editing room and doing what they want, instead of what we got in its place. Overall, this is is just a fantastic mess.

As an avid comic book reader, I was never fond of the Fantastic Four (established 1961), sure they have some compelling space story lines, but I always felt they worked better in a larger spectrum with other Marvel characters (in the comics). Whether it is Reed geeking out with his other science bros like Tony Stark (Iron Man), Dr Hank Pym (Ant Man) & Peter Parker (Spider-Man) or when the Thing takes (or at least tries) on the Hulk or Invisible Woman/ Sue Storm aka Sue Richards having an undeniable chemistry with Namor (Marvels version of Aquaman) or Logan (Wolverine), this four characters (including Johny Storm aka Human Torch) just together living as a family never really interested me much. Well except for the exception of their main antagonist Dr Doom (IGN ranked him as #4 on best villains of all time). But yet as a huge fan of the super hero genre, it is disappointing to see how despite millions of fans (& story lines),  the Fantastic Four have never seen a good Big screen adaptation. There was a movie in 1994 made by Roger Corman (king of the B-Movies), which was never released. It was only made to secure rights for a friend, and is stuff of pure cinema legend and sought out by cult film fanatics. If you've seen any YouTube clips of it, you know it's terrible (Update: the movie has found its way online). Let's fast forward to 2005, where the guy who made the 'Barbershop' movies director Tim Story was given the opportunity to make a 'Fantastic Four' movie. If you can recall it, you'd remember it was pretty enjoyable yet, Jessica Alba was really the only memorable thing from the movies, or at least the most talked about. Nevertheless, the film was a box office success enough to guarantee a 2007 sequel 'Fantastic 4: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)' which was pretty awful.  'Fantastic Four' is one of those Marvel properties that has yet to be turned over to Marvel itself, and is still owned by 20th Century Fox, which is unfortunate, because that studio still has no clue what it's doing with this franchise. That brings us up to date with 2015's reboot directed by Josh Trank. Trank's only other credit was the awesome "found footage" superhero film 'Chronicle', but supposedly Trank is very difficult to work with, which is why he was booted off the upcoming 'Star Wars' film. Whatever good 'Chronicle' had going for it is non-existent here with 'Fantastic Four' and seems like it's one long set up for something yet to come. Right from the production & the casting (controversial casting of Michael B Jordan, an African American actor in an essential white role), the film has been making news for all the wrong reasons. I think the first major clue for me that this movie was doomed (no pun intended) was, the 1st trailer itself! A super hero film trailer which was not exciting! Even duds like Elektra & Ghost Rider had better looking trailers. Another major clue for me that this movie was doomed was its running time of 100 minutes. Why? Because when you have a film like this - a reboot, where it has to introduce various new characters, set them up and a new premise/universe, the movie isn't going to be an hour and a half long. It's going to be two hours. Those extra twenty- thirty minutes can make a difference. For the record, the first two Fantastic Four movies had around the same running time. The original film was only six minutes longer. But that movie wasn't the best one, either. I reminded myself of X-Men. X-Men was a great movie. It had a similar running time, but not the same task, as it wasn't a reboot, well kinda. Yet as the first installment in a franchise, it did a fantastic job at setting things up. Yet, with Josh Trank at the helm & a talented cast of Miles Teller (who was awesome in Whiplash last year), Kate Mara (exceptional in Netflix' House of Cards), Michael B Jordan (brilliant in Fruitvale Station) & Jamie Bell (excellent in TURN: Washington's Spies), I wanted to give this film a chance despite the wide spread negative reviews pounding the internet. In my opinion, its not as bad as the reviews are pointing it out to be, in the sense its not 'the worst superhero film', like common did everyone forget Batman & Robin, Elektra, Hulk, Iron Man 2 & Catwoman? This is a film very much out of time and place in today's market of superhero movies. Ten or fifteen years ago a studio might have been able to get away with it but not today. Audiences like to be entertained and with the competition offering much more excitement, I don't see audiences taking to this, at all.  The film's plot really potential & it does manage to have some great moments, but it just takes too much time to become interesting, long enough to make us not care. The story follows young genius, Reed Richards, who at the beginning of the film, working on an experiment that attempts to construct a teleportation device. It was hardly a success as the object they've sent to who-knows-where, never returned. Seven years later, now teenage Reed (Miles Teller) is again trying his luck on the same experiment. The attempt yields a better result but is still dismissed as a magic trick by his high school teacher, but not by Dr. Franklin Storm (Reg E. Cathey), who at that moment, is drawn with utter interest to Richard's experiments. The meeting brings Richard's feet to Baxter Institute where he is joined by Storm's adopted daughter, Sue (Kate Mara), his son, Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), and his ex protegee Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell), to work in completing a larger and more advanced version of Richard's device. The success of their effort prompts their team to send all of them four to their target alternate universe, but the consequence is far worse than they could imagine. It's easy to dismiss Trank's Fantastic Four as an unfortunate victim of superhero fatigue that emerges in the wake of the continuous influx of superhero movies inundating the big screen, but you can't shrug off its fatal narrative flaws that include unfocused pace and bland character developments. The latter may have been completely covered by the actors playing the two-dimensional characters, but ex-positional defects keep sending them to becoming something the audience might find hard to care about. Perhaps its the ill-contrived rationales behind how all the often-sense-deprived proceedings work, that keeps the film constructing a form, worth-of- attention, or the forced CGI-gimmicks that strip the sense off the moment's supposedly strong sentiments, that hampers its spectators' ability to absorb its message, and thus, feel that the dangers these characters are about to face, is real. Either way, it's difficult to care, much less find reasons why we still should. The running time really is a problem. This film is rushed beyond belief and its plot is nonsensical. The characters' introductions are decent enough, particularly the Fantastic Four, but their roles throughout the rest of the film are disconcerted. Exposition can be tiring, but after the exposition ended and the action was supposed to pick up - it didn't. Second, the plot. As I said above, the film's plot seemed interesting. It had potential and it looked like it could go somewhere, especially considering how superhero movies nowadays have managed to flesh out their stories and make them very enjoyable. There are even hints at awesome things to come at certain points. But the film's in shambles. You hope and feel it will go somewhere, but in its hour and a half running time, it feels so empty. One of the reasons for that is the third thing, the writing. The writing isn't good - the film's climactic conflict feels backed up into the end of the movie, because there wasn't enough time to set it up. The writing caused the pacing to be terrible - transitions between scenes weren't good and some scenes either went on for too long or were far too short. Speaking of "things", The Thing is entirely CGI. No make-up, costume or anything - just a giant, naked rock monster. Yes, he's naked, too. Not even any shorts. Huh. But yet, in his shortest screen time, he will probably be the only thing you remember. Did I talk about Doom? I don't get it why cant FOX just stick to his comic book origins? It may sound a bit flashy, but its anything better than what they have been providing us with. Sure the Doom here is way more efficient & creepy than the previous films, but what is with him being this dis grunted blogger, & shouldn't they have mentioned he is going to appear on screen for only five minutes or so. Doom makes an unsurprising return here as their common enemy, driven by a fusion of body and alien matter to cause global destruction and around whose defeat to ensure the survival of planet Earth becomes a rallying call for the team to unite despite their differences. It is one of the dullest and most unexciting finales we've seen in a Marvel movie, not least for the fact that it doesn't know how to collectively bring together their superpowers except in a tag-team fashion to distract their opponent. There's probably some salvageable remnants left in Fox's previous attempts to bring one of Marvel's most popular superhero team to the big screen. That's maybe what Fox thinks in pushing this new adaptation, given how franchises keep being rebooted and resurrected these days, assuming either lighter or darker takes, to pull away themselves from the shadows of their previous (most often, forgettable) forms. The latter is more evident with this film, as Director Josh Trank, puts a darker spin to it, employing a grittier feel to its plot. While that is true and recognizable, there's no denying of its desperate efforts to emulate its Marvel predecessors. Trank's intention of emphasizing the tension within the quartet is evident and admirable, but is ultimately undone by a script that doesn't develop it in any substantive manner. Worse still, it leaves an audience looking for visual spectacle severely wanting, that not even a very busy third act manages to salvage. The way the characters get their powers is more interesting and more realistic, and the team is assembled, but they skip any kind of training montage to a single display of their abilities which are not yet honed, we skip all that to introduce the main villain. He is majorly overpowered for reasons unknown, but the action finally begins, only for the movie to end after the first and only super showdown. On the whole, 'Fantastic Four' is a not so fantastic effort to build a franchise! Despite a likeable cast, a weak story,  a cringe worthy script & average special effects, the film turns out to be one of the most disappointing films I have seen all year. To be honest I was really enjoying the movie until the end and it straight up didn't deliver after making us get to know these characters, and making us wait to see the good stuff! I don't think this 'franchise' needs to crossover into any other universe, be it preferably Marvel and not X-Men, as it's got enough potential to hold it's own, and I'd give a sequel a chance because it's a step in the right direction, which is still scheduled for a release on June 2017.

Normally I write a small introduction and a small synopsis, but with this film I will omit that as I have a lot to say about this. Let's start with the controversies/geek problems: Johnny Storm is African-American? Irrelevant, Michael B. Jordan is a good actor. It is not a faithful adaptation of the source material? As far as I understand this closely follows the Ultimate Version. Josh Trank is a problematic director? Bryan Singer had those problems in the first "X-Men" film and everyone loves that. They disrespect these "iconic" characters? Honestly this super team is extremely silly and dated due to their 60s origins, and even Marvel killed the F4 comic books as they are so focused in their CU (that is truly a disrespectful move to fans). This looks like the worst super hero film of recent years? Have you seen "Daredevil", "Elektra", "Thor", "Thor: The Dark World", "X-Men Origins Wolverine", and "The Incredible Hulk"?! A comic book film is supposed to be comedic and colorful? The best super hero trilogy - "The Dark Knight Trilogy"- is dark and sophisticated; it is not a bad thing to go to this direction, just because it isn't made by Marvel Studios that doesn't mean is awful, but of course it depends on the execution. Is this the worst super hero film of all time? It isn't worse than "Superman IV", "Batman & Robin", or the examples named earlier. It is the worst Fantastic Four film? Have you seen those last three films?! There is nothing lower than that. 
With all that being said, "Fantastic Four" is a mess. It is horribly edited, the CGI is horrible (I haven't seen CGI this bad in a summer blockbuster since "X-Men Origins"), the characters are underdeveloped, the villain is laughable, the second half is dreadful, a rushed and laughably incoherent ending, and it is incredibly short for a comic book film. But even if it suffers from those colossal problems due to the creative issues and the problematic production, this isn't the abomination people claim it is (a lower score than "Quest for Peace", "Pixels", "Jupiter Ascending", and "Howard the Duck"? You got to be kidding me). The first half of this film had potential as it has character development, the cast deliver the best performances they could (with the exception being the not so well utilized Kate Mara), some of the imagery is good, the "Chronicle" style works perfectly with this characters, and there is even a scene that tries to emulate Cronenberg¬¥s body horror. 
"Fantastic Four" is a bad movie, no doubt about it, but it isn't an abomination. It had some potential in the first half but then it all disappeared. Don't pay attention to the RT score or most of the audience reviews, as they are Marvel fan boys who hate every non Marvel comic book film. If I had left halfway through this, I'd be giving a much better score. As far as "origin stories" go in the world of comic book movies, Josh Trank's take on the "Fantastic Four" had the novel approach of viewing their powers through the lens of a horror movie. Indeed, the body horror element and the gritty level of realness that Trank brought to this film made it something special... right up until the second half kicks in and then suddenly you have no idea what direction it wants to go. Not to delve too much into the backstage drama that this film went through, but you can't help but wonder who's to blame for squandering such a fresh spin on a superhero property - a meddling studio, or an indecisive director? There were definitely pieces of a good (and probably great) movie in here. It's just that you can see all the glue that is loosely pinning the bad bits onto the good bits. Not only was the movie rewritten and reshot DURING filming, but entire scenes and set pieces that were already shot were dumped in favour of the studio's vision for a better movie. Which is a real shame! The first half was sooooo decent, I thought. It's not the worst movie of all time (as some blind haters will have you believe), but I just can't tell anyone to go see this for themselves if they're paying for it. This is only worth seeing if you're curious what a big budget car crash looks like, or if you're just genuinely curiously (like I was). Again, it's not terrible... but it's just not good either.

Fantastic Four (2015) is the reboot of the comic book franchise. It is about a group of teenagers who gain powers and changes them physically after they visit a different dimension. The previous incarnations of the comic book were a little too campy and ended up not being so great. This version isn't much better. I will say this though: it is definitely less campy and the first hour actually isn't too bad. It's the 2nd half that brings it way down. The payoff for all the set up is terrible. After getting their powers, the movie jumps forward a year so we don't see them develop at all. The 2nd act gets kind of boring and then the final act is too rushed and Dr. Doom is horrible. He reappears too quickly and the final fight starts and ends too quickly. For these reasons, I can only give it a 2/5.

There are no great surprises but the effects work well and they avoided the tendency to have whirling motion blur which blights so many films nowadays. Watch this if you've seen Mission Impossible and are waiting impatiently for Man from Uncle.

This movie is not AS bad as people are rating it. It has some major issues but those all start at the second act. There is no reason for this film to have the same rating as Catwoman. There are about 10 other films I can name that are way worse and are physically painful to watch and yet everyone is declaring this as the worst Superhero movie in existence but it simply is not so. With an excellent cast giving great performances, the film starts to fall flat when the primary members of the fantastic four get there powers. It's here that the editing suddenly gets spotty and we see that the CGI is in need of a tune up. 

 Even so, it's also at this point that we do get a pretty good (albeit short) action scene featuring Reed Richards and a few cool scenes with Doom living up to his name.  So everything about this film is not trash as others would tell you, there are bright spots amongst the chaos.   I personally believe everyone should experience this film and draw their own conclusions because I feel like it's worth seeing even if to hypothesize the ways in which you would fix it.

  I won't spoil the ending but that's definitely one place I'd like to focus on if I were fixing the movie. It's like the studio wasn't sure how wrap it up so they just opened a book of clich√© endings that no one wants and just picked at random. All and all, while the film has a lot of issues, I still appreciated the parts where it was actually good. Don't let the overreactions fool you, there is some good in this film.  -Nerdyvideos.com

In a time when superhero films are blossoming, Fantastic Four is the dead, wilting rose in the bouquet that everyone will ignore. It's sole purpose is to set up a universe for crossovers with much better films and it fails in glorious fashion in doing that as well as being any smidgen of entertaining or fun.

Guess what. It isn't an abomination. Fantastic Four is a very confused film; it's confused about what it wants to be, what it wants us to want it to be. It has a different vibe. It's not The Avengers and that is good. It has its own character. It has humor, subtle humor, youthful humor. It doesn't have to be in your face, it just has to be there and it is. The team as a team was not expected to be fully functioning -it's an origin story. The main actors were exceptional, especially Miles Teller and Kate Mara. The story was compartmentalized; the first part worked just as it should have; the different tone and set, gave it character. The second part also hit its mark: the science, the depiction of powers. All these were very well done. The third part of the movie, though, felt rushed. Victor's motives were not questionable; the stage had been set for what he wanted since the beginning. I did not mind his depiction as a mad/creepy genius, essentially, but there was something rushed about its conclusion. The visual effects were sometimes satisfying, others, a bit disappointing, that much is true. But other than a hurried ending, and slightly unsure pacing, the movie did not suffer at all. As an origin story, it served the characters well. Not everything has to be an over-the-top colorful firework of a superhero movie. If it was up to me, I would not give up on these characters. If the creators learn from their mistakes, I expect the sequel to be a lovely experience.

"It's clobberin' time," said someone to the prospects of this being a successful movie franchise.

I've never been particularly close to the FF. I have only a couple trades (because my favorite writer was involved), and I generally think higher of the previous two movies than others. What '05's FF and it's sequel got right, I think, was the sense of family amongst the characters. Whether or not related by some biological or legal technicality, they still cared about each other; their rapports and relationships were very apparent. When Johnny made fun of Ben, sure the Thing would get angry, but we understood that Johnny still loved Ben like a brother/cousin/what-have-you. We did not get this in the latest installment.

What we get is a Reed Richards whose more of a thoughtless jerk, a Sue Richards that needs to abandon emotions to show how smart she must be (which has been done with female characters in other movies), and a Ben Grimm who we come close to feeling for, but is otherwise unmolded as a character. Johnny Storm cracks a little wise, but he doesn't seem to know or get along with Ben as well as he should. His first scene with his sister, and they don't even make eye contact! What's that about?! (Side note: With an adopted Storm child, that could've only *emphasized* the themes of family...but again, they weren't really played strongly in this venture.)

Victor Von Doom may not've been the blogger I kept hearing he was, but he seemed to jump to "destroy the world" style villain with little back up. I get that he didn't want "the evil government" to pollute the alternate world, but destroying Earth is too big a jump for the first in what (they'd hoped) would be multiple movies. In this character's case, it'd be a refreshing twist if they'd made him a dictator.

Now, there were a few moments that weren't absolutely horrible. Reed not knowing what a fist-bump is, Johnny ripping on Victor, and even some elements of the final battle were decent. But then you have heads exploding, in a movie that's supposed to be about Marvel's First Family, and it just reeks of over-effort for "edginess". Seriously people, watch it before letting your kids see it. You shouldn't have to for an FF movie, but this time, you absolutely do.

If nothing else, let this be a cautionary tale to all future comic book movies: Grey, sterile environments, darkened or jet-black costumes, heaps of cynicism and moral ambiguity, hyper-/extreme/graphic violence and people looking more depressed or angry while hardly ever smiling, doesn't work in every property. The reason people have enjoyed the Fantastic Four for as long as they have, is because of their family bonds, the light-heartedness and, yes, even silly aspects of comics. The same is true of the likes of Shazam/Captain Marvel, Superman, and numerous others. Making things, "dark", "gritty", "edgy" and "more real" doesn't always work for escapist entertainment, or at least not in every facet of the plot and characters. A bad story will be apparent no matter how "hip" you try to mask it.

Bleakness of visual, characteristic and narrative tones is not "realism". It's just depressing. Hint hint, Warner Bros./DC!

Fantastic Four is the newest superhero film to be released and stars Miles Teller, Kate Mara, Michael B. Jordan, and Jamie Bell. It is the third live action Fantastic Four movie and is a reboot of the Fantastic Four series. I have never been a fan of Fantastic Four. I never read the comics and I didn't like the previous two movies. We have all heard the bad buzz surrounding this film. From the film's director, Josh Trank, showing up drunk on set to studio interference, most of the buzz surrounding the film has been bad. I also was not impressed by the trailers and so I walked into the film with very low expectations. With all that said, Fantastic Four is one of the worst superhero films ever made. The film is nothing but exposition and attempting to set up a movie universe like the Avengers. Everything about this film is terrible.

The characters themselves are terrible. They are all boring and suffer under this terrible script. They don't have any chemistry with each other. Even though they are supposed to be a team, nobody really seems to like each other and you never really get that team feeling from them. The cast however is very talented and they do the best they can with what they have which isn't much. The cast's decent performances are the only somewhat redeemable thing in this movie.

The villain of the movie is Dr. Doom who is one of the worst super villains to ever appear on the big screen. From the very first time we meet Dr. Doom he is a rude and boring jerk with no villain motivation. A good villain should be likable despite the fact that he's the villain but Dr. Doom is so bland and boring. He also looks terrible, his suit basically melds into his body so he looks like he's covered in green plastic and doesn't even have a moveable mouth. He is about as far away as they possibly could have made him from being the Dr. Doom from the comics. Basically how he becomes Dr. Doom is (and trust me I'm not spoiling anything) is that he touches some green liquid which causes a huge eruption and makes the team run to their spaceship and he gets left behind. He's gone for the entire middle act and then a year later, they go back to the planet, and find him, and bring him back to earth. He immediately starts killing everyone and says he feels at home on the other planet and wants to basically rebuild Earth on the other planet. But why? There isn't any set up for any of this at all. Yes, he was always a jerk, but he wasn't homicidal and there is no reason whatsoever for him to want to kill people and destroy earth, it's so rushed. 

The film has terrible dialogue as well. At one point, Reed Richards is trying to convince the team to steal the machine they can use to go to the other dimension. The problem is that they have been forbidden from doing this and Ben Grimm says "Hey man, we can't do that because they will find out we left". and Reed's response is "Hey man, don't worry about it because by the time they realize were gone, we will already be back"! The way he said that made it sound like they were about to sneak out to go to some party down the street but I'm like dude your going to a different dimension, that's a little bit different. Another horrible example is when they need something from the government and the government agent says "What if we say no"? and the Thing growls like he's a dog and Human Torch says "Say yes". Shut up Human Torch, just get out of here.

The film visually is terrible. The CGI is some of the worst effects to put to film. The character designs of the Human Torch and the Thing were the worst. It looks so fake, there is nothing convincing about it. The lighting is terrible as well, most of the movie is so dark, and there is a blue lens over the camera for a good portion of the runtime making the whole film look dreary and depressing. The film had a budget of one hundred and twenty two million dollars. Ant Man had a budget of only eight million more dollars and that film visually is excellent. You would think that with this money behind it they could make the CGI just a little bit better.

The script for the film is of course the main problem. The movie itself is so short for a superhero film being barely ninety minutes. The film is just so boring. There really is nothing but talking the whole time and there is next to no action. The only real action is at the end when the Fantastic Four has to fight Dr. Doom but it's not really a fight it's more of a dance. They just dance around with Dr. Doom for thirty seconds and then SPOILERS! Dr. Doom dies because the Thing punches him into an energy beam. It's just so stupid and lazy. The film is so serious as well, there isn't anything fun or lighthearted at all about it and it makes the movie so unenjoyable. The characters aren't' even referred to by their superhero names or even the Fantastic Four until the very end where they don't even say the full name, they just hint at it because they're so embarrassed they're just trying to finish the movie.

Overall, Fantastic Four was god awful and it has nothing to offer anyone. There is a sequel for this film planned in 2017. Don't expect to see the sequel to film in 2017 but instead expect to see a reboot in 2023.

Final Rating: 1/5 Terrible.

Every movie  has its flaws, but the newest Fantastic 4 attempt is far from the abysmal trash that people are making it out to be. The ending may have been a tad anti-climactic, but at least this time Doom wasn't defeated with a fire hydrant.

Fantastic Four, or Fant4stic, as it is ridiculously marketed, is a terribly miscast, horribly written, baffling abomination of a film. Josh Trank (Chronicle, a far better movie) is out of his element here, crafting a dull, nonsensical, morose reboot of, in hindsight, an immensely better saga.

Miles Teller is Reed Richards, a teenage scientist with an invention: a teleportation device, created with the aid of pal Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell, who seems out of place here). Together, they catch the eye of Dr. Franklin Storm (The Wire's Reg E. Cathey) and adopted daughter Susan (Kate Mara, in a noticeable wig) at a science fair and are shipped off to the "Baxter Institute". There, they meet Franklin's biological son Johnny (Michael B. Jordan, also of Chronicle) and hilariously-named Victor von Doom (Toby Kebbell, who makes the previous movies' Julian McMahon look like Olivier). Together, these young scientists create a machine, which transports matter to "Planet Zero", said to be a home to great energy. 

Of course, they go. Reed, Johnny, Ben, and Victor all travel to the other world, where everything goes wrong: Victor is presumed dead, and the other three (and Susan, who was impacted by energy that they brought back) receive powers. Reed can bend, twist, and elongate his body. Johnny has the ability to burst into flames. Susan can shift in and out of visibility, and can also create force fields, and Ben is entirely composed of rock, and is, as a result, very strong. They're all fine - their "biochemistry is off the charts", whatever that means - and are sent into combat by the government, including a shady, gum-chewing Tim Blake Nelson.

Hang on, did you really think von Doom was dead? Of course not, and he looks like a metallic red skull - in other words, ridiculous. His eyes glow green. It's laughable.

I'm not joking when I say that some of the lines in this movie are atrocious. "There is no Victor. There is only doom!" "All this power, and he's the source!" Yuck. The screenplay is credited to three, including Simon Kinberg, and he should know better - he's written smarter, better films than this, including last year's terrific X-Men: Days of Future Past.

Don't see this movie. The CG is spotty, the characters weak, the acting extremely poor, and the writing and direction reeking of Uwe Boll. It's a step back for the team in film, and it makes Tim Story's installments with Ioan Gruffudd and Jessica Alba look like The Avengers in comparison.

Before going to the theatre, I heard rumours that Fox deliberately put out close to zero promotion for this film, and now I know why...The film, a reboot of its 2005 and 2007 predecessors, sought to retell the origin story of the popular Marvel superhero team, but this time with a more serious, darker tone. I found the movie's plot (if there was even one to begin with) to be choke full of plot holes and inconsistencies; the actors' performances looked really bland and so devoid of emotion at times, that I Just couldn't make any kind of emotional investment or connection with any of the characters. The movie as a whole (save for maybe the ending climax) was so lacking in soul, I almost fell asleep halfway through the viewing. And the fact that most of the scenes in the film just takes place in a giant lab didn't help either. Just about the only saving grace from this film was the splendid soundtrack, composed by the duo Marco Beltrami/Philip Glass. Looking back at this film, it really makes me wish they had just continued with the original Fantastic Four cast from before. Hiro's Score: 1/5

Is this the best movie of the summer? No. Is this Fox adaptation of a Marvel film the best Marvel film? No. Is it the steaming pile of poop everyone seems to think it is? Nope. It has its flaws, mainly being that Dr Doom is a villain that deserves his own movie and doesn't work when rushed into the last act of one. The editing is choppy, the scenes are rushed. But every time Miles Teller is on the screen he steals the show. The movie left me wanting more, and hoping they learn from their mistakes and make a better sequel. The developmental hell this superhero reboot went through unfortunately destroyed it. I am very sad to report that this movie is the worst Marvel movie ever, the worst movie of the year, and worse than both original Fantastic Four movies. It's boring, stupid, unfunny, and an abomination. The movie tried to be less silly than the others and more serious and brooding, which was a terrible mistake. These heroes are ridiculous, have fun with it. But it tried to be the Dark Knight of the series and failed miserably. The script is pretty laughable, the relationships between characters feel awkward and forced. This doesn't feel like a team, they feel like some strange people forced to work together. The first hour is tedious, it takes forever for anything to happen and when something does happen (getting their powers) it's hilariously bad. So then the movie flashes forward a year instead of being smart and letting us see how this team learned to control these unique abilities and work together. The final act of this movie was the final nail in the coffin for the movie, Dr. Doom (who looks awful) wants to destroy the world for rushed and unexplained reasons. He now has a full suit and wants to be called "Doom" (HOW SCARY!). So the final fight lasts no more than 2 minutes with the team beating him up, then it ends with some cringeworthy dialogue. So it sets up a sequel so much it doesn't even try to be good. It's dull, uninteresting, and feels like it was written and directed by a 5 year old. Fantastic Four ts .5/5 stars (F).

I understand that when it comes to changing one or two things just so you can adapt a comic book into a two hour movie. I can also understand that it is always best to be absolutely fair no matter how much shit the press, critics, and even Rotten Tomatoes tell you how bad a movie is before its release. If you are a true fan of comics that you like, it is only fair to go see it in theaters at least once. I am an open minded person when it comes to these sorts of negative reviews, but this is something where I have to agree with the 98% of the overall critic's out there. I mean GAWD DAMN what in the blue freaking hell did I just watch an over hour ago? So the premise for this one is that FOX decided to change up the origin story a bit by giving these four their powers not from outer space, but in another dimension. Alright, that's fine and dandy because it is a nice change of pace and takes a chapter from the Ultimate Fantastic Four storyline. But everything after that, well.... FOX should just sell the rights back to Marvel already so they can clean up after their filthy ass mess.

This film had me going for a little bit with Reed and Ben's origin to showing off how smart he is. But after they get to the Baxter building scenes it is drawn out for so long with a montage of them just working together for a long time and it takes the movie almost AN HOUR for them to get their powers. After that it's just like they spend a year of their lives working for the government doing black ops missions, to one of them being on the run because he escaped, and even their base of operations is a military base itself that the US government just hands over it to them. That is NOT how you write a Fantastic Four story! Not to mention altering almost every single main character in here from Dr. Doom looking like a greasy hacker with authority issues, to Sue Storm being ADOPTED from Kosovo, to Tim Blake Nelson who should have been the Mole Man but wasn't. I had no problem with Michael B. Jordan as the Human Torch, but I kind of wished he would have done more with that character like make out with a random hot chick or prank the Thing behind his back. The only thing the I like about this where the their super powers which were good, especially from Sue Storm which I thought was a lot better than Jessica Alba's powers. But overall, there were so many changes to these characters and so many alterations that I would actually much rather prefer to watch any of the other three previous Fantastic Four films than watch this abomination of a comic book movie. Which is why I give this one sad lonely little star.

I decided to give this movie a try, despite all the awful reviews.  Surely, I mused, it couldn't be as bad as nearly everyone was saying.  I remember seeing the phrase "joyless" in reference to it, and clung to the hope that they were wrong.  These characters deserve to have a great movie made about them, and I thought that, perhaps, the reviewers were being too critical.  After all, I really am fairly easy to please when it comes to movies.  I can find something to like about nearly any movie, and honestly derive a sick kind of pleasure from watching the "so-bad-they're-good" types of movies.  Troll 2 is one of my favorites, for example.   But this...

The reviewers were all right.  Listen to the reviews, kids.  Soulless, bleak, lacking in basically everything except cliches.  Not even an hour in, I broke down and abandoned ship.  I ended up giving my dog a bath, fixing my broken-down desk, deep cleaning my stove, hanging new curtains and doing all my dishes instead of finishing it.  

I would only recommend this movie if you *really* need to get motivated to do housework.  I found it to be even more effective than watching an episode of Hoarders.  

Movie wise, I give it half a star out of five As far as motivation to get you off your ass and away from the damn movie?  Ten out of five, easy.  This might be my new go-to movie for "I really need to clean the house, but am going to put on a movie instead and try and procrastinate," because it was incredibly effective at  NOT letting me do that.

The characterizations weren't fully fleshed out. Even Reed Richards, the pseudo main character, wasn't more than the basic science nerd. Sue Storm's character was more interesting as she came off as more stoic. Female characters, especially ones who are a love interest, are not typically stoic. Honestly, my rating would be a lot higher if that was intentional instead of unsatisfyingly unfinished. Still, Johnny's character was the most disappointing. He's always been a hunk and the strongest reason my friend and I went to see the film. He starts off as a rebellious grumpy race car driver, and shifts almost abruptly to the nicest member of the team. The short montage of the members working together isn't enough for the character shift. It was almost whiplash. Doom is an appropriate skeez the entire time. No complaints there. Ben was perfect. Near the end of the film I couldn't help noticing plot hole after plot hole. My favorite is where did Doom get his villainous cape?
             
It was still more enjoyable than the Green Lantern.

You poor bastard of a movie. The extreme hate for you has been equal to no other (that I can recall). Almost at your inception, you were met with volatile criticism you most certainly didn't completely deserve. Sure, you made mistakes along the way. Not every decision you made along the way was sound. I would've loved for you to take a different road in life, but you are what you are. Maybe if the times were different, and people a little less cynical, you'd have stood a better chance. You're not as bad as the world makes you out to be, but you're not as good as you could've been in more loving hands. It wasn't your fault entirely. Soon, I'm certain, you'll achieve a certain cult status, and be seen and judged more objectively. My advice for the future: develop your characters (it'll be nice to know who they are and what their motivations are); mold a steadier plot (you were a little erratic in that area); get out and see the sun (too dark); also have some fun (the world isn't as bleak as you believe, besides, you have a family that loves you). Hopefully, you've learned from this and will be stronger for it. Keep doing what you're doing. I think you'll be alright. One last thing: you might be tempted with a "marvelous" offer in the near future. If i were you, I'd take it.

Growing up, I never really read comic books, but I did enjoy 2 superhero shows. The first was Super Friends, and the other was Fantastic Four. 

I can't stress enough how ridiculous the backlash has been for this film. I made the mistake of accidentally catching the review consensus this time before watching it--something I absolutely hate doing. But I did, and therefore spent the entirety of the film expecting it to be terrible. It's no Godfather, but it's not The Last Airbender either. This movie is entertaining, riveting, visually stunning, and far more inventive with its origin than the previous series.

With a much darker take on the classic comic book series, director Josh Trank has us immersed in a world that's already somewhat dystopian. High school genius, Reed Richards (Miles Teller), gets recruited to a team who is developing a machine that can teleport organic matter to an alternate world. He, along with Sue (Kate Mara) and Johnny Storm (Michael B. Jordan), Ben Grimm (Jamie Bell), and Victor Von Doom (Toby Kebbell), gets super powers from the energy contrived by this mysterious world. 

As filmgoers, we tend to take each adaptation of a film as the definitive version. This doesn't happen in literature. While Frank Miller did catch some flak for darkening Batman in his Dark Knight Returns graphic novels, overall the feedback was positive and today he is credited by many for revamping the series.

This new Fantastic Four isn't perfect by any means. The dialogue is shoddy, the setup takes up 2/3 of the film, and there isn't enough action to satisfy a room full of Comic-Con attendees, but I couldn't stop watching. The first 45 minutes or so feature some of the best cinema I've seen all year--full of mystery and intrigue. While I grew up with the cartoon version of the Fantastic Four, I have an appreciation for the dismal tone of this film. It's something new and edgy. 

I did feel, however, that the direction is a little sloppy. As much as I love Miles Teller, I feel like I'm watching some of his bad takes rather than a final cut. Also, there is no purpose for using a CGI monkey over a real one.

But overall, I would watch this film again. It has one of the best Marvel movie villains to date. And although most of this film is a setup, it takes one for the team and provides a solid foundation for future films in this series.

Do NOT believe the haters.  This is a terrific movie.  I came in knowing absolutely nothing about it, never having been a regular Marvel Comics reader and having only seen one Marvel movie previously (Guardians of the Galaxy).  I did not read a single review prior to seeing the movie (a practice to which all serious moviegoers should adhere, to avoid being unfairly influenced).  Now that I am reading the reviews, of both critics and audience members, I am astonished at the level of hatred being directed toward this movie.  Trust me; nearly everything you read is inaccurate.  In fact, the movie is engrossing and entertaining from start to finish, the plot well-developed, the characters interesting and empathetic, the action scenes exciting.  While I cannot speak for lifelong Marvel fans, on behalf of us newbies, this is a great movie.  Guardians of the Galaxy was entertaining, but did not have nearly the pathos or depth of Fantastic Four.  Go...and enjoy!  Thanks for listening.

Well it's finally here. The big over-hyped and over controversial comic book film third try is a charm Fantastic Four. How does it hold up? It doesn't. However is it as bad as critics and fans say alike? No, not even close. I'll admit, I didn't hate the movie. I was deeply disappointed, but I didnt' hate it. The whole film for one is way too short and for two a whole lot of nothing happens. The movie as a whole feels just like one big set up for something bigger and throughout the whole venture you expect just that; something more. It's the epic Blue balls of Comic book film history. A terrific cast squandered on a soul less origin story. You are never invested in any of these characters. Nobody's personality pops out as particularly special or interesting. Then ending, which comes out of left field is tacked on and pointless. It's one of those oh yeah we forgot this a comic book movie and we have to put a villain in here to fight and defeat, but it's all just bandage dressing. The wound had already been bleed out by this time and they were just putting a bandaid on a tourniquet. I'll say this however, if this film was a pilot for a series on Sci fi channel or Fox, it would have worked. And mostly thats where the problem lies. It doesnt feel cinematic. In a comic book world of Captain America and even fox's own X men it just doesnt feel big enough. Who knows? Maybe Fantastic Four might be better served as a weekly television series or even a event series on Netflix. That would give the creators more time to flesh out it's ideas, themes and even it's characters. Because as it stands this film is unsatisfactory. Again, not good, but it isnt the worst Comic book film every made. I'm tempted to say it's at least better than the other two efforts. But saying this film is better than those two films is like saying being shot in the head is better then dying by lighting yourself on fire.

It's clear that Trank took everything fun and fantastic about the comic and made it humorless and ugly well before the obvious studio tinkering. The first hour favors labored explanations of nonsensical pseudo-science over forging meaningful emotional connections between the characters. The horror-based character effects eclipse any effort made by the perfectly capable cast. The worst of these is a toss-up between Doom's clunky computer animated shell and Sue's on-again-off-again Halloween quality wig. Very little action occurs until the last twenty minutes, a conclusion so underwhelming and dull it appears to have been entirely shot through a bottle of Windex. This movie is wrongheaded in tone and direction on just about every level. I didn't expect much going in and got a lot less than that.

The critics have unfairly magnify the flaws of the film. 

No doubt, the film is painful to watch BUT not because it is horrible (on the contrary, there are some moments of greatness) only because the realization of how great it could have been were it not for 20th Century Fox's interference. The film's cinematography/setting/mood/atmosphere were amongst the best of the genre.

Hope Josh Trank, like David Fincher before him in Alien 3 can bounce back from a dismal film not of their fault. Based on what I've seen, it is just a matter of time.

"Fantastic Four" is the reboot of the Marvel franchise about the group of scientific researchers who travel into an alternate dimension and gain unspeakable super powers through the energy on the planet. In the film, Reed Richard's friend Victor Von Doom gets stuck on the alien planet and becomes a product of its energy, Dr. Doom. The Fantastic Four are left to fight Dr. Doom before he destroys Earth by sucking all matter into the alternate dimension. As a reboot, I thought this film was flat and hollow. The character development is not near what it should be, and the underdeveloped characters make for underdeveloped action sequences. The final confrontation is not nearly satisfying enough, and it feels like the film goes by in a blur. This is watered down version of more competent Fantastic Four films. Miles Teller and Michael B. Jordan (That Awkward Moment) are out of place in this film and look older than the teenagers they play. We didn't need a Fantastic Four reboot but got one anyway. I just wish the director had put more into the characters and fight scenes ------------------------------------------------------------------------- C

Fantastic Four is a film that takes it's time to let us experience the characters before and after their transformation. Avoiding typical cliches of military weaponizing of their new abilities was unexpected, but refreshing. The actors were good enough to not need much dialogue at all. Overall the film felt great and could've benefited more from a less effects heavy messy climax they had. I had a feeling while watching that the film was a straightforward sci-fi flick instead of a superhero movie, and I liked it based on that. In a way the film would have been better if I had never heard of the Fantastic Four. Summing up, it's a character driven sci-fi movie that turns into a generic superhero climax. I was hoping for some philosophical resolutions instead violence, but that's just what I wanted and that may not be a fair expectation from me.

Fantastic Four's return to the screen is not a great cinematic achievement, but it is not the worst comic book movie ever made.

While the film suffers from some pacing issues, it deserves to be lauded for delivering one of the most honestly acted set of performances in the genre. Where the brightly colored denizens of the Marvel Cinematic Universe strut, preen, and wear their emotions on their sleeves as they inexplicably pummel each other, this is a cast of characters who, despite their young ages, act more adult than just about any other comic book movie adaptation. 

Where the film fails is in the excitement department. The same seriousness the cast brings to their performances is echoed in the pacing of the film, which comes across as somewhat plodding. There are moments of excellent, though, which suggest that director Josh Trank may have set the stage for a more exciting film in the future, now that his core cast have learned to have a little bit of fun with each other.

I've not been to see a film with such a terrible buzz around it in a while. I'll be honest, I needed to see this film to get a Summer Blockbuster special offer (free tickets/snacks) from my local cinema, otherwise I might have given it a miss. There is superhero fatigue for one thing. Yes, Marvel manage to keep the genre sparky and fun most of the time, but the X Men films and the recent Spider-Man films have been a bit of a chore. 
It doesn't seem that long ago that we had Ioan Gruffudd, Jessica Alba, Michael Chiklis and Chris Evans fail to set the screen alight with a competent but very dull pair of films. This time the cast are younger - yes, it's that unoriginal idea 'The Origin Story'. *sigh*
In an unnecessarily long opening sequence we meet Reed Ricards and Ben Grimm meeting as kids, when Reed tries to build a teleporter. Skip forwards a few years and they are recruited by Professor Storm to assist his daughter Sue and maverick student Victor Von Doom to build a transport device to visit a different dimension. The lads decide to be the first to make the trip once the device is finished - but leave sweet little Sue at home. Unfortunately, the trip goes wrong, Victor is lost and the other three end up with weird powers. Sue has reached the lab at this point and gets hit with a blast too. Stretchy man Reed escapes but the others become government guinea pigs. Time to revisit the alternate dimension - but an old friend is waiting for them...

This film is not quite a bad as I thought it might be from the bad press. The problem is it has no humour and not much real excitement. The end battle is predictably crash bang but amazingly naff. Sue's floating bubbles look really stupid. The stretchy arms SFX is barely better than a cartoon and Jamie Bell's Thing is...well, just a lump of rock!  The pacing of the film is all wrong as we spend far too long with the build up to the kids getting their powers but hardly any decent USE of their superpowers. One nice gun battle with Miles Teller bending his way round bullets, but that is about it. Poor Kate Mara is mis-used about the worst, the script making her a very boring character - yet of course the young men must fall for her as she is the traditional comic-book token girl. Mara looks half asleep most of the time and barely cracks a smile. Miles Teller shows even he has him limitations. I've never been a big Jamie Bell fan. To me he's always been a one trick pony - a career made from one great role as a kid - Billy Eliot - and never been particularly good in anything else. Here he is barely onscreen as himself although if he is inside the motion capture suit for Ben I guess it gave him a job! 

If there is one good thing to come out of the huge flop of this film, will it be for Hollywood to PLEASE try to see beyond comic books and action. There is a line of thought that the more creative and interesting work is being done on TV these days, and when you compare films like this uninspiring, turgid mess to Orange is the New Black, Transparent or Sens8 on Netflix and Amazon or Breaking Bad, Game of Thrones or even the much more interesting TV superhero shows like Arrow, The Flash, Agent Carter or Daredevil on Netflix, it is hard to see the relevance of Hollywood films like this if you are not a straight, young, white male.

I hope Fox learns that what they did to this movie ruined it, and will hopefully either do better in Fantastic 4 2 or sell the rights back to Marvel. It is worth a watch to judge it for yourself and not just read what myself or others think about this movie.

Bafflingly, fascinatingly, *powerfully* bad, this movie legitimately makes me retroactively enjoy Tim Story's FF entries so much more. The problem, the more I think about it, is just that this was a heavily marketed blockbuster superhero film...which is completely unfinished. By which I mean, neither Trank nor Fox were CLEARLY not done with either of their cuts of the film, but Fox decided to mash them together anyway. 

For proof, look no further than the final couple of scenes, and particularly the atrocious character modeling on The Thing and Human Torch. Nothing really happens for the first hour, stuff kinda randomly happens for the second half hour, and then it's over. Sample dialogue:

Doom [CHOKING REED]:
'Reed Richards....you always thought you were smarter than me'.

Reed [GASPING FOR AIR]:
'....I am smarter than you.'
[THE THING runs up from behind and PUNCHES DOOM into GREEN CGI LAVA]

This movie was good when it started. The characters were bland, but likable, and the writing was decent, but forgettable. It had a good story going for it with the idea of inter-dimensional travel, and some decent cautionary undertones about how the government can have skewed priorities. Then they had the accident, and it all went downhill form there. The story was suddenly rushed, the undertones became painful overtones, the character choices suddenly made no sense, and they stuck the final peg in destroying what little semblance the characters had to their comic book counterparts.

Reed's character in the second half was inconsistent, Sue's bland as hell, Johnny's a selfish and rebellious ass, and Victor Von Doom is miles away from who his character is in the comics. The only one remotely true to the comics is Ben, but that's one out of five, which isn't good. Add to it that there's nothing that makes Sue and Johnny seem anything like they're siblings, the fact that there's absolutely no real feeling of them being a team until that five minute climax, and said climax and ending being so rushed it's like a case of whiplash, and you get a Fantastic Four movie that's even worse than the first one.

If they had taken the first half of the movie and extended it into something of its own design (along with some tweaking to the writing and characters), this would have been a great film about the discovery of another dimension. But no, Fox decided to grip onto the Fantastic Four copyrights like an eight year old refusing to let go of a toy and yelling "MINE!" They got greedy with wanting another comic book movie franchise and now they're paying the price with hilariously under-performing box office numbers and well-earned bad reviews, as they deserved.

The first feature length cinematic release of the Fantastic Four I thought was solid. I am in the small minority who actually liked the Tim Story Fantastic Four. Was it great? No. It wasn't even good, it was just solid, it gave a faithful origin story to Marvel's first fully formed Superhero family. Jessica Alba's casting aside I thought it ticked the right boxes for a Fantastic Four origin story even if it lost it's way towards the end, with lots of logic issues cropping up.

Now fast forward 10 years, we get this piece of nonsense. This film is just meh!, that's what it is. The film is too dark for a Fantastic Four film with exploding heads definitely pushing the 12A rating's boundaries. The characters have very little personality. Yes it's more serious compared to the cartoonishness of the original, but still did they need to be so bland. 

In the 2005 version Chris Evan's was a saving grace he captured the essence of his character, the prankster, the ladies man, the hot headed, the care free lifestyle in essence he made you believe in his relationships with those around him. In this film Michael B. Jordan's Johnny Storm is a hot head not much more, he's angsty with daddy issues and has no chemistry with Mara whatsoever.
Kate Mara, Miles Teller and Toby Kebbel are all solid with their roles unfortunately the story gives them very little to work with. Jamie Bell should have been the stand out, but unfortunately he is very lifeless in his stop-motion work, and his character reflects the darkness of the film. 

The original film took a lot of flak for Michael Chiklis' character and the prostethics used, I personally thought he did well with his character and could be related to. This film sees him start off (ahem) grim and continue all the way through until the last five minutes. In general the film lacked the humour which was frowned upon in the original film.

Overall an unengaging film too dark for it's own good, with serviceable action and characters, the actors and the audience really did deserve better.

When a movie is as terrible as Fantastic Four, there is sometimes a redeeming quality; it makes you laugh because of how stupid it is, like Batman & Robin. Fantastic Four is so boring and bland, that you can't laugh at it. The whole film is building up to an epic showdown, and when you reach the climax, it is so terrible because there are no stakes, no real danger, and it is absolutely  terrible because (Spoiler Alert) Dr. Doom gets battered in FIVE MINUTES! He's supposed to be the greatest supervillain of all time, and he looks so stupid! This movie fails on every level! DO NOT SEE THIS! I went to see this with a group of friends and my seven year old brother, and leaving the theatre the only person who LIKED the movie was my little brother, because all he cares about is the stupid action! Thank you for reading, and DON'T see this movie.

Fantastic Four
	Initial Reaction:  Just what are they fantastic at?

	Main Characters
	Johnny Storm/The Human Torch, Reed Richards/Mr. Fantastic, Ben Grimm/The Thing and Sue Storm/Invisible Woman: They're the Fantastic Four played by Michael B. Jordan, Miles teller, Jamie Bell and Kate Mara

	Plot Summary
	Reed Richards is a really good scientist - even at an early age.  During his school years, he creates a portal to another dimension.  But it doesn't work very well and it causes a black out.
	Years later, he's given a second chance.  Now an adult, he is able to perfect his portal to another dimension.  While the military and other big pocket companies watching, he successfully tests the machine, sending a monkey to the other dimension and back.
	But Reed isn't happy when his work is going to be used by others - and not by him and his friends.  So he gathers up the other guys in the group - Johnny, Ben, and Victor - to be the first humans to visit the other dimension.
	When they get there, they start looking about at some strange goings on (a really bad idea).  And when they poke around at the energetic phenomenon going in front of them, things go wrong.  
	There's lot of explosions and a whole lot of strange energy being tossed about.  Reed and company have to bail out.
	However, Victor doesn't make it back with the rest of the group - and when they do make it back, the trip fundamentally changes them (along with Sue who was remote piloting the device back from the other dimension)
	This is how they become the Fantastic Four - and they are put in lockdown by the military (except that Reed escapes and is now a fugitive.)
	And things take a turn for the worse when Victor makes a re-appearance as Doom.

SCORING
Main Characters
	There's not much going on between these four.  I get that Reed and Ben are best friends.  But outside of that, there's not much chemistry between the four of them - most notably between Reed and Susan.  SCORE: 4

Supporting Cast
	Doom is supposed to be one of the most iconic villains in the Marvel universe.  But even though he has a great look, he comes across as your typical bad guy out destroying the world.  And the rest of the cast isn't much better than that.  SCORE: 2

Plot
	The first act of the story is great - when Reed and Company go into the other dimension.  However, the rest of the film feels like a Cliff's Notes version of a much longer story.  Main details are left out, and the main plot felt rushed. 
	What's even worse is the final battle is a major letdown.  SCORE: 2

Originality
	This feels like a second rate Marvel film - and there are a lot of them that's out now on demand or streaming or whatever.  SCORE: 3

Violence Factor
	There's a lot of scenes where the Thing and the Human Torch battle tanks and planes - but it feels like they should be fighting something more meaningful.  Besides the last fight is resolved via a bunch of mumbo jumbo rules that don't make any sense (to me).  SCORE: 2

Other Moral Issues
	This is supposed to be about how a group of friends and family form a unique fighting force for the good guys.  But they spend so little time together after getting their powers that the message is lost.  SCORE: 3

Final Score (out of 60): 16		% Score: 26.67%
	This is a Marvel Film?  Really?  It felt like a rushed project that is doomed - I mean Victor Von Doomed - to fail.

Well, I'm on the fence. On one hand, it's not what I expected. On the other, I didn't feel it was as bad as I've read over the weekend. I think my expectations are what's killing this, and let's be fair. Technically being a 3rd (if you count the mid-90's mess as the original) reboot for the franchise isn't helping at all.

What it got right: I liked how they presented the powers. Compared to the last outing for FF where everything felt "cartoony", they did a good job presenting their abilities in the film. From Sue's ability to control things to Grimm actually looking more hardcore and beefy...I think they did the groups power sets justice. Also, the plot was ok...but read my next section for the downside of this. The characters were good and the acting was fine except for the occasional forced cheesy-ness.

What it go wrong, sort of: They spent too much time in the beginning of the film trying to ground and flesh out characters without actually doing so. By the time you get to the meat of what you really came to see, it's way too rushed. The conflict is done in 20 minutes, leaving you with roughly an hour and 20 minutes of attempts to make the film overly serious. They could have done a better job fleshing out the characters and their relationships...and they honestly should have been able to do it faster. But even if not faster, they could've extended the movie easily by another 20-30 minutes and really fleshed out the conflict and ending, giving movie goers more to bite down into. The story wasn't bad, it was just far too rushed after the slow start.

However, to say it was abysmal...that's a stretch. When I watched Elektra, I couldn't even finish it the first time. The second and final time I watched it, I regretted finishing it and wanted my wasted time back. Did I enjoy Fantastic Four? Sure. Could it have been better? Absolutely. However, I'm kind of upset because I didn't think it was "that" bad, and now that it's on a road to failure (critically), I'll likely never see this franchise again...which is kind of sad since it's one of my favorite Marvel groups.

If you like comic movies, and are just looking for a good time without oscar performances and the highest caliber story...then you'll probably enjoy this about as much as I did. If I had to give a reason "not" to see it, it's mostly because this input into the Marvel catalog of movies will unfortunately be forgotten and left for dead...so don't expect to see #2 in 2017 like it was originally slated.
