We all have heard of the problems that were being reported about the Fantastic 4, and after hearing how bad it was before going to see it, I was really skeptical but very interested to see how bad it would be. Needless to say my expectations were at an all time low, especially after the films director tweeted that it wasn't his film we would be watching but a studio hack job that had been hijacked mid way through the filming and editing process.

The first hour of the film, I was thinking the critics were being too hard on this movie. The set up of the characters was actually well done, with the exception of doom and Johnny storm, the concept and tone Trank was working with did have a cool sci-fi horror thriller feel to it, but after the climatic trip to the "other universe" (not a spoiler it's in the trailer people) the film completely unravels and goes from the cool sci-fi horror flick and reverts back to the shitty campy movies from the early 2000's.

The biggest problem with this movie is that everything about this movie screams B-list SyFy movie of the week. For the most part the movie is boring, the soundtrack is dull, the action is almost non existent,  and whoever edited and worked on costume design on this piece of shit movie shouldn't be aloud to work on a super hero film ever again.

The outfits of the "fantastic four" weren't bad per say but they were very basic and forgettable; Doom's look on the other hand was horrible. He looked like a combination of the robot from Metropolis and Imhotep from the Mummy remake got a hold of some kryptonite.

The Thing didn't impress me like he seemed to everyone else, his look was just passible in my eyes and the sound of him matched with his mouth movement was god awful.

I keep reading in reviews that this is by far the best Fantastic 4 movie and there I'm going to have to disagree. As bad the last two films were there was at least fluidity, humor,  and accessibility. Yes the movies weren't good but at least young kids, who watch shitty movies and TV shows anyway, could still watch it and have fun with them or at least it was a campy movie that the family can go pick up from redbox when the cable goes out, this film just sucks for everybody.

It's too bad we will probably never see the film Josh Trank was making, and if the first half of this film is any indication of the route he was going, I'm sure he would of given us an interesting film like his 1st on Chronicle.

I would pass on this one, unless it's to check out how much of an epic fail this movie is or just watch the first part of the film and leave, becuase trust me whatever you come up with in your imagination will be better than what happens in the second half.

The 8% critics rating is totally unjustified.
The film is good, I really enjoyed it. I think the reason it has scored so low is either because  the critics are five year old children who prefer the god awful, cheesy as hell Tim Story version which had an overweight middle aged short bloke in a halloween costume instead of The Thing, or they just wanted to be hammered with over the top cgi action scenes. What I think is that the critics haven't realised that It isn't supposed to be the same sort of film as the Avengers or Iron Man, which I do think are great films by the way, its just that this is a different type of film which although it does have good (if not many) action scenes it's more focused on introducing the characters and the origin story as a whole, which would then lead to an amazing sequel (if they make one). It's not cheesy, like the previous incarnation and it does have some amazing scenes. Yes it could have been better, maybe if it had extended the final battle, or kicked in a bit earlier on, but all in all the film worked for me, it was so much better than I expected it to be after reading the reviews. The acting was good, the film looked good and moved at a good pace. It is not really a children's film though, not that it's not suitable it just doesn't try too hard to be funny and it isn 't ridiculously over stuffed with action. I must also add that I read the Fantastic Four comics as a child and I am a big fan so I was aware of the fact that they did stray from the source material some what, but it didn't matter as I was already over this before I even saw the film, and it still worked.
To summarise I would say that it's definitely worth watching, and much much better that the previous version. Ignore the critics they are probably just influenced by other reviews and are jumping on the hate bandwagon.

It was too serious, and when they tried to lighten up with a little humour, it failed miserably.  Take the final scene for example when trying to decide what to call themselves.  Talk about being tacked on. 

Since casting was announced, reactions were largely negative despite the actors all being talented in their own right.  Miles Teller portrayed the iconic if not younger Reed Richards quite admirably I must admit though, as was Toby Kebbell's menacing performance as Doctor (Victor Von) Doom.  you can easily tell that the pacing of the film was all jumbled as the first act of the film was in fact the best part of the movie. 

Don't think I'll be sitting through this again, unless Director Josh Trank gives us a Directors Cut of the movie, as it looked obvious that outside interference had tampered with Trank's vision of the film.  Mind you, it could have been more serious than it already was.  Ugh, Fox - will you let go of the rights and sell them back to Disney/Marvel if need be.

Read all the reviews and what people said about the movie and finally watched it. It is not that bad as people and critics (whose opinion should not be taken) make it out to be. I say watch it for yourselves and make your own judgment. There are plenty of other very bad movies out there besides this one and this movie did not deserve to be trashed. 

Now that that is out of the way, the movie does have some story elements that do not make sense. I do not think it is feasable for a kid to teleport something using a science experiment to another dimension and that some one professional would come to a high  school science fair looking to recruit a genius when he could vet students at MIT or other schools to do so. This is where the movie starts to come into trouble is with the writing. Reed and his friend get recruited and help finish a project started by a former student named Victor Von Doom. In a short summary the team wants to be first to travel to another dimension and as a result, gain powers and are taken in government custody. The movie tends to use this to drive the movie forward and in the end, Victor wants to destroy this planet and start another one. The way in which Victor does so is not clearly explained and this is where many people thought the movie floundered is the final confrontation. It seemed that something was missing and the stakes were not that high. The plot hole of how the four heroes survive on the other dimension is not explained and so is many other things in this movie. 

To say the least, the movie as it is, it is not that bad. I thought it was entertaining to an extent, but I was not overwhelmed or had that sensation of enjoyable emotion from other superhero movies like Man of Steel or the Avengers. I will recommend this movies to fans of superhero movies to rent to see and judge for themselves instead of listening to other people's opinion. It is worth a rental if not, wait for it to debut on cable.

Up to the aftermath of them receiving their powers, the movie was an okay science fiction flick and had A-list actors been included, this part probably would have gotten half-decent reviews.  However, after Reed disappears, the movie goes straight downhill faster than Rosie O'Donnell on a runaway skateboard on the streets of San Francisco.   And who ever would have thought that a script could completely devour the talent from such proven young actors?  Oh, and was it me or was Reg trying to make Dr. Storm into Nick Fury?  
Here's what I hope.  These actors deserve a second chance at this and their careers BETTER not be negatively impacted.  They deserve a decent script, a great storyline and an amazing director.  They are all incredibly talented actors who don't deserve what this horrid film is casting upon them.

What happened? Josh Trank's "Chronicle" is SO GOOD. How did it go SO BAD? Is the goal just to make a bad Fantastic Four movie every ten years? Obviously there were some good ideas here, some talented young actors, and even a good scene or two. The scene where Doom reveals his powers is one of the most genuinely horrifying I've ever seen in a movie, and I'm surprised they were able to go that dark in a PG-13 superhero movie. But other than that: the film has no rhythm, the climax takes place at what, narratively, feels like the middle of the story, the relationship dynamics are all over the place, an the special effects just look bad most of the time. There's very little color or fun, and it feels like there are no real locations. This feels like the pilot for a mediocre Syfy show. I'm even going to say it: I like the 2005 version better. Seriously, how did things go so wrong?

Lots of things to say about this one, especially given its headliner-worthy "bomb" status. But to summarize, in the end this was probably only slightly better than its '05 rendition. Problems exist, yes, such as a lack of character motivation or really any energy at all. Even Johnny's "sass" seems muted and diluted. But at the same time, there were parts of this one that I liked more than its predecessor (not that everything should have to be compared to the preboot, but it just makes it easier). For example, in my opinion, almost everything about Victor von Doom was better, save for the aforementioned motivation problem. So while it may not deserve any massive accolades, it even more so doesn't deserve the diatribe that has ensued.

Fifty years of fans and stories all go down the drain in under two hours. 
I don't even have to read the comic books to know this reboot is not remotely faithful to the source material. Director Josh Trank and Fox are all to blame for this hot mess. It is as if they purposefully did not want the film to be associated with the comic books. The team name and the nicknames of the team members are never uttered. It takes an hour before they all get their powers and when they do, nothing happens. The main villain doesn't appear until the 75 minute mark and then the climax is rushed into the last ten minutes and then it's over. There is no action or excitement. The cast, who are all talented individually, have no chemistry together and they are too young to be playing these types of characters. The dialogue is laughable and the films takes itself too seriously. A film like Batman can be dark, because it is Batman. Fantastic Four is hardly Shakespeare. Even the Jessica Alba/Chris Evans Fantastic Four knew it was cheesy and went with it. This reboot makes those films look like Citizen Kane. The entire experience was dull, boring, and uneventful. There is no sense of fun, excitement, wonder, and entertainment. You can't have a title with the word Fantastic in it and do the total opposite. I can't believe it was possible, but we have a comic book film that has little to no action or anything comic book related. This is not only the worst comic book film I have ever seen, but it is one of the worst films of the year. 

Grade: D-

First before you see this film, you need to realize that this reboot is based  upon Ultimate Fantastic Four, not the classic comics.  The beginning of the film is spent on character and story development.  Since this is an origin story, the characters develop their powers late in the film so there is very little action for most of the film.  

There are no scenes during or after the credits.

This did not feel like a typical Marvel film. If I wanted gray tones, "realistic" showcases of superheroes, and an upbeat franchise grit it up, I'd just re-watch "Man of Steel." Marvel films are often light-hearted fair, films like "Guardians of the Galaxy" and the more recent "Ant-Man" seem to be aware how ridiculous the very concept of live-action superheroes is, they have fun with their premises and it reflects in the success of the films. 

The Fantastic Four comics and cartoons have always been some of the silliest and light-hearted of Marvel franchises, and this film completely abandons that aspect. The film tries to be "modern" but really just goes for gritty and existential, showing how frightening the sudden changes the four go through would be in the real world. That is all well and good if you're watching a Cronenburg or Lynch film, but this is a comic book movie about four friends who get blasted by rays until they can punch through walls, and melt a tank with a flick of the wrist. The director, Trank, claimed on Twitter that a year ago he had a version of the film that was much better, but that we sadly "will never get to see that version." The only response to Trank's whine about the film not doing so great critically is that he should've made that film instead. 

When news first broke of the re-boot, it was said that it would be a "modern" and more "realistic" or "grounded" retelling of the superhero group. However when it comes to superheroes, most people simply want to have fun. I don't want to look at the Human Torch and feel bad about how his powers have irrevocably changed his life and how he is a military tool, I cant feel sorry for a man who can fly and shoot fireballs (no matter the version, The Thing gets a pass on this). I want to see these all of a sudden powerful people take the gifts they've been given and use them to stand up for a world rendered powerless by the villain (of course Dr. Doom in this one).

The effects definitely look better than the first two FF films, though that's to be expected ten years later. Plot-wise this film was angsty and the characters rather dull, a disappointment especially when compared to the string of successes Marvel Studios has gone through in the past few years. The film is sure to get a sequel though, and we can only hope the next movie will make up for the problems that plagued this one.

The film made me really sad, and it's broken on many levels. The acting is wooden, the special effects are weak, and the direction is simply poor. Above all, it's missing heart, which I feel is not only essential to super-hero films in general but really important for the Fantastic Four. I thought that shifting tones would be a positive effect for this movie, but it's a complete misfire and I hope Fox does the right thing and return the property to Marvel.

Then we come to the third act...I have no idea what the heck this part of the movie was trying to be but whatever it was, was just an abortion. How act three ended up the way it did is beyond me because even though the tone of acts one and two differ they go together in a way that does make sense. The Fantastic Four movie (My review)
Four things that they did wrong with F4 (according to me):

First, the vilain is unknown from most of us.  When you ask someone :"Name a vilain." Do you think "Von Doom" is in the Top 10? 
Probably not and the hero is as good as the hero is bad. Get a real vilain, nobody cares about Von Doom

Secondly, travelling through space and seeing it (the flashy tube and all the clouds) is always boring in a movie. 
Nobody took notes when they released Green Lantern in 2011.
Even in the Stargate TV series they cut that part out and all they did was travelling through space
In the movie, they called it "Interdimensional Teleportation". They should revised the dictionnary a little bit. Teleportation involves desintegration.
Anybody saw Star Trek ?
If the characters stay has a whole inside a force field and move inside a flashy tube. It is not "Teleporting", it is "Travelling".

Third, we don't care how the characters get their powers. They should already have them at the beggining of the film so we can see some action
Then you put a five minutes flashback scene that explain how it happened. Also keep it simple: Hulk = Radiation, Spiderman = Got bitten, Superman = Alien
F4 = They build a thing to go somewhere and while trying the thing, something went wrong and bla bla bla... See my point?

Four, for a superhero movie you must respect the basic plot: Fight the vilain and loose, enhance the superhero, fight again and win
In F4, they got Von Doom on the first try.  So Boring! I told you at point 1 that Von Doom was not up to the task. He's not a real badass

Bonus, Never use the plot: "military trying to use the hero as a weapon". It always failed in a movie, because miliary have to failed. 
You cannot have a super hero turned into a weapon, it failed in the first two Hulk's movies, it is the boring scene in Jurassic world.
Don't do that..ever

I found the film watchable, there's some cringe-worthy bits but on the whole, I found it a huge step up from the last series.

Kate Mara will never be a good actress to me. She is statuesque, robotic, and has no charisma whatsoever. Any scenes she has with Miles Teller (who I happen to think is a good actor) are just the most awkward thing I've ever seen. She gives him nothing to work with.

I like the actor for Doom. He did really well, but Doom's motivation and (villain) design had some major problems. Villain Doom looked like something you'd see in a puppet shop in Germany. The frozen face looked doll-ish and didn't allow the actor to emote whatsoever. Also, just how the hell did he manage to survive not only the fall, but for a year on a foreign planet with no oxygen or food or even the ability to eat/drink?

There are just some references and lines of dialogue that don't help the movie at all. "Dr. Doom over here." was a completely unnecessary line. We get it, he's the bad guy, you don't have to bludgen us in the face. They should've downplayed that and made him more friendly initially towards the group, it would've made his transformation better.

"It's clobberin' time" needs to go or at least underplayed. Even if Grimm's bully of an older brother had said that to him as a kid, that would've been fine. But it's ridiculous for a super hero to have a battle cry in this day and age.

Things I did like: Michael B. Jordan as Johnny Storm. He did a good performance. I know this is a can of worms but I'm not sure why the change in ethnicity. You ask any professional writer, if you're going to make changes to source material, it needs to make the story better, you can't just change things in order to be showy. However, I enjoyed Michael B. Jordan as Johnny, so maybe the decision to make Johnny Storm African American was made after Michael B. Jordan killed it in the audition room. Maybe he did so well, they made the change after casting him.

I liked none of the heroes aside from The Thing having hero aliases. The tone of the movie was too dark and dreary to include something as campy as "Mr. Fantastic" or "Human Torch".

I liked the design on Ben Grimm as The Thing. It's certainly much better than the orange, rubber suit version we got in the last iteration.

I liked how the team came together at the climax of the film. It wasn't over the top, or cheesy.

On the whole, like I said, it was watchable. Not anywhere near as good as it could've been, and that's not the fault of the cast (with the exception of Kate Mara) or Josh Trank. You could see the parts of the movie that were well written and then every once in a while you notice where good ol' FOX manages to shoe-horn in their own "Hey remember these jokes" moments and their dated and formulaic money-making strategies. It's simply a case of what happens when bad producers and executives get their hands on a good script.

This script could've been really well at a different company.

Ripping the latest Fantastic Four reboot seems to be the sport du jour. While the news about the impending negativity this movie would spark has been circling the media for nearly a year, my inherent fandom of comics in general made this a necessary film for me to see. While not a huge fan of the previous two movies (I've never seen the bootleg from the early 90s), generally speaking, Fantastic Four is a difficult story to interestingly bring to the screen. It's very cosmic in nature, has a long history of some very strange villains and story lines, and can be kind of boring. In the 2005 initial outing, the good things included a very good origin story, representation of Ben Grimm as a pilot and a perfect Johnny Storm. However, Dr. Doom was horrible. Not representative of the comic version at all. Jessica Alba's ethnicity came across strangely as a blonde woman. And, while looking like the very early 60's Thing, the orange suit was...just bad. The second movie, centering around Silver Surfer was a much better representation of the comics, in spite of the weird Galactus. The stories overall were very weak and too goofy. When I heard they were going to reboot it, I was ok with it, for the recasting of Dr. Doom alone.
Fast forward to the introduction of Josh Trank as the director. Someone who had done ONE film. Yes, it was a decent film, but given that he was handed the keys to the FF reboot AND a Star Wars film, I was confused. So...fast forward again to nearly a year ago when word came out that the movie was in trouble. Josh was acting erratic. He had destroyed the house he was staying in while shooting in Louisiana. Fox secretly told Disney that Josh would be a bad idea to keep on staff for the Star Wars movie. Then suddenly, Josh was off the Star Wars film while rumors were abound that he had abandoned the final steps in FF post-production. The studio had come in and held reshoots and was completely in control of editing. So much bad press that nearly no one was looking forward to this movie coming out. Marvel was grinning like a cheshire cat wanting to get the rights to making FF back in the House of the Mouse. Then word came that an embargo was being put on all screenings and release of critical reviews until 2 days prior to opening day, always the kiss of death to a film. Then...3 days ago, the embargo broke and the messages were loud and clear. This movie was horrendous.
I still planned on seeing the movie, but after Sony destroyed anything interesting about Ghost Rider...twice...I wasn't feeling good. Expectations were in the toilet.
So, this morning, as I'm making my way through the surprisingly short (one hour, forty minutes) reboot, I was pleasantly surprised. The acting, even from the kids at the beginning, was very strong. The characters were coming together well. While the origin was different and the inclusion of Franklin Storm, Sr. and a mixed-race Storm clan was...well, unnecessary, it worked. I was buying it.
Then they got their powers. From this point forward, it's like a completely different director and/or editor ran the film. There was essentially only ONE action scene. The end. And it lasted mere minutes. Without spoiling what led up to that one action scene, I will simply say that Doom was introduced. A very good Dr. Doom. Character and actor-wise, I very much like this flavor of Fantastic Four. And the tweaked origin introduces the potential for much more cosmic inclusion. The potential is exciting to this comic fanboy.
The problem is, from the point where they go their powers, which was on a planet that required CGI and special effects, I was confused as to where the budget went. The effects were some of the worst I've ever seen. Just awful. So many story points were shortened, sped up and left to the viewers interpretation and assumption. Weird considering how well-paced the story had been until this point and how well-developed the characters had been. For the final 40 minutes, character development evaporated. The effects were horrible. There was no story. Just...scenes. Leading up to a very short and shallow action scene. Then...it just ended. A short, quick wrap-up, not to mention dumb, especially considering how strong the film had been the first hour. I simply couldn't understand why the film shifted tone and pace so quickly.
As a result, I couldn't give it more than 2 stars. I believe Fox should give the rights back to Marvel or, at the very least, allow this film to have a sequel with a PROVEN director.

Fantastic 4's major problem is not so much that its dull, but without the right balance of it's own feel and heroics to make it a story worth backing. While aesthetically the film is mostly pleasing, everything from the well performing cast to the great visuals should make this an enjoyable film. But it's the story's underwhelming and heartless feel that causes a big problem for this movie.  While the cool, youngsters feel coupled with it's mostly strong supernatural element do work, it is hard to back purely by the lack of interest in the characters. The cast is relatively small making for little variety, little cheer yet strangely little time developing who we do get. Johnny Storm is pretty passive, while Ben Grimm is massively sidelined with only Reed getting a decent slice of the pie. The lack of interaction between the characters is even more concerning, especially for a team film, where certain members don't even seem to utter two words to each other. The biggest flaw however is with the film's villain whose motives are pretty weak, but also looks silly and whose powers don't make sense. His enterance leads to a rushed and out of nowhere finale that has little to no build up, feeling the film doesn't even have a proper middle or end act. While the actors should be proud of how they helped this film, Fox can probably feel this franchise slipping from their fingers as Marvel rubs it's hands together for another score.
